item.content:encoded:
Click to read the briefing

Listen to Richard Strauss’ Don Juan for orchestra and read the score.

Write an essay or around of 1500 words discussing this piece.

Among other things, you may wish to include:

  • some background information on the composer
  • an overview of the story on which the composition is based and a discussion of how the music conveys the story
  • a discussion of the piece’s Romantic properties
  • the instrumentation and observations on how the orchestra is used
  • other musical observations which connect with topics covered in this chapter.

Include musical examples as appropriate. Find a balance between the ‘facts’ surrounding the piece and your personal views.

Richard Strauss Don Juan, OP.20, 1954 RCA recording with the Chicago Symphony and Fritz Reiner

Richard Strauss (1864-1949), a child prodigy with exceptional musical aptitude, composed two symphonies and concertos for horn and violin by the time he was twenty years of age. He hailed from Munich and was the son of Franz Strauss, a celebrated horn player who held Mozart, Beethoven, and Haydn in high esteem as his “musical trinity” (Kennedy, 2006).

In 1874, he attended the Ludwigsgymnasium where he studied music theory with Friedrich Wilhelm Meyer, conductor of the Munich Court Orchestra. During his studies with Meyer, Strauss learned about Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, Mendelssohn and other classical composers.

By the time Strauss was 18, he had already written around 150 pieces in a conservative style that resembled Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert. But at 21, he began to rebel against this traditional sound.

In 1885, he moved to Meiningen to work with Hans von Bülow, a renowned conductor. He learnt about opera from Brahms and perfected his conducting technique, while being exposed to the two main currents of Germanic music at the time. Those advocating “pure music” (e.g., Joachim, Hanslick) hailed Brahms’ music and opposed those who propagated “music of the future” (e.g., Berlioz, Liszt and Wagner) (Malheiros dos Santos, 2018).

Strauss met Alexander Ritter (1833-1896), a composer and violinist in the Meiningen Orchestra, who had an immense influence on him. An avid follower of Wagner, Ritterer shifted Strauss’ focus from abstract works towards modern orchestral works inspired by literature. This was despite his father’s disapproval of Wagner’s music. In 1889, Strauss completed his first mature masterpiece Don Juan (Dotsey, 2019).

The idea behind composing Don Juan was born in 1885, during a performance of Paul Heyse’s Don Juans Ende in Frankfurt. However, Strauss’ direct source was an incomplete poem from 1851 written by Nicolaus Lenau. In contrast to the classic conception of Don Juan as a rake and impostor, Lenau portrayed him as an idealist searching for ultimate love, eventually becoming discontented with himself.

In his composition of Don Juan, Strauss focused on the individual pursuit of an idealised form of love that perpetually eludes him. This is expressed musically through a continuous rise and fall in emotion that culminates in the protagonist’s demise by duel.

Strauss wrote Don Juan for a large instrumental ensemble consisting of 3 flutes (3rd doubling piccolo), 2 oboes and English horn, 2 clarinets, 2 bassoons and contrabassoon, 4 horns, 3 trumpets, 3 trombones, tuba, timpani, triangle, cymbals, glockenspiel, harp, and strings.

Strauss’ structure of Don Juan mirrors the story told by Nikolaus Lenau, beginning with a presentation of the protagonist, followed by two episodes of love affairs and an orgiastic scene which leads to a duel with Don Pedro resulting in his (assumed) death.

At the outset of this piece, Strauss employs the whole orchestra to create a boisterous, heroic rising pattern which adds vigour and propulsion to the main theme.

The initial scene (beginning at 00:56 of the recording I listened to) appears to be the introduction of Don Juan’s initial conquest and romantic relationship with a woman. There is a duet between the violins (woman) and horns and cello (Don Juan), that culminates in a very interesting and surprising dark climax at G.

The second scene (at 05:32) appears to be another conquest by Don Juan, suggesting a greater emotional connection this time. The plaintive flute and especially the endearing oboe melody are employed to convey the ardour of his love. This sentiment ultimately reaches a triumphant high point as the horns play the heroic theme.

The carnival scene (at 10:27) functions as a transitional section as it spirals out of control. It starts with tranquil strings, but quickly gains intensity and creates an intense atmosphere. As the scene progresses, Strauss juxtaposes various iterations of Don Juan’s theme on top of one another.

The fight scene (at 15:00) maintains the tension built in the preceding scene, ending suddenly to echo Don Juan’s death at the hands of Don Pedro.

The death scene (at 15:37) is an understated and sorrowful conclusion with the bassoons giving Don Juan a final breath.

Listening to the full piece is clear that Strauss uses the full orchestra and its individual timbres to express Don Juan’s emotional journey to the audience. At the start, he is portrayed as audacious and confident through sweeping arpeggios and complex orchestration. His love stories are tender and romantic, with Strauss employing range, colour and instrumentation to illustrate the character’s humanity. He accentuates Don Juan’s boldness through powerful instruments such as brass while utilising woodwinds to depict his insecurities.

Strauss’ use of dynamics is a notable feature in his composition of Don Juan. As an example, it ranges between ff and fff only for woodwinds, horns, and strings in the A. Another example is the beautiful slow movement in L, which ranges from p to ppp. In addition to conveying the storyline to the listener, this creates an interesting contrast that prevents the music from becoming monotonous.

The exact structure of Don Juan has been a source of detective work for the past century, with the piece being described by some as a free sonata and by others as either a rondo or a fusion between the two (Hepokoski, 1997). Nonetheless, it is clear that Strauss wanted to move away from conventional structures.

Romantic-era composers sought more open ways to express their musical ideas, instead of the strict forms used by classical composers (i.e. Haydn’s sonata form). With this newfound freedom, they could employ melody, harmony and texture to evoke a narrative, a character or an atmosphere; thus new genres such as Programme Music, Concert Overture and Symphonic Poem were created.

In the collection of his thoughts, Recollections and Reflections, edited by biographer Willi Schuh, Strauss voiced his support for these novel orchestral forms. He stated that “New ideas must seek out new forms for themselves: the basic principle adopted by Liszt in his symphonic works, in which the poetic idea really did act simultaneously as the structural element, became from then onwards the guideline for my own symphonic works.” (Strauss and Schuh, 1974).

Strauss was aware of the pioneering progressions in Programme Music from Liszt, a pianist who revolutionised programme music with his novel genre, the symphonic poem.

The term ‘symphonic poem’ describes a programmatic work composed for an orchestra which draws inspiration from a range of outside sources, such as poems, stories and artwork. This style of composition was adopted to meet nineteenth-century aesthetic objectives; by relating music to something non-musical, allowing multiple movements to be combined into one section and raising instrumental program music up to the same level as opera (Macdonald, 2001).

In addition, composers of symphonic poems had the freedom to alter the stories and characters, as Strauss appears to do with Don Juan. It remains uncertain whether he is faithful to Lenau’s representation, or if he uses melodic themes and orchestral colouring to suggest a character who is more actively engaged with life rather than one who is jaded. This could be described as the enchantment of romanticism in art, expressed by their search for unlimited possibilities in composition which allows listeners to enter into a realm of introspection and imagination rather than being restricted by form.

Strauss also drew much influence from Wagner, particularly in terms of chromaticism, harmonic structures, and the use of leitmotifs. In his composition of Don Juan, this is evident through the varied orchestration and gradual evolution of motifs to evoke drama and emotion. These musical ideas effectively convey the psychological nature of its characters.

It wasn’t just the piece’s structure and the use of the motifs that made Don Juan innovative. The piece demands great technical virtuosity from its performers in terms of range, breath control and virtuosic execution, as in A. This is emblematic of the Romantic era which sought to develop great technical virtuosity.

In summary, Richard Strauss’s Don Juan is a remarkable example of Program Music from the Romantic era. It displays his aptitude in utilizing various musical elements to convey the protagonist’s inner world whilst simultaneously stirring emotions in its listeners. Through the incorporation of leitmotifs, chromaticism and technically challenging orchestral parts, Strauss has produced a sophisticated and powerful composition that reflects music’s capacity to narrate stories.

References

Malheiros dos Santos, P.S. (2018) Don Juan, op. 20. Available at: https://www.filarmonica.art.br/educacional/obras-e-compositores/obra/don-juan-poema-sinfonico-op-20/ (Accessed: 29 November 2022).

item.title: Listening to Franz Liszt – Les Préludes
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Les Préludes is a symphonic poem composed by Franz Liszt and premiered in 1854. His symphonic poem is…
item.content:encoded:
Les Préludes is a symphonic poem composed by Franz Liszt and premiered in 1854. His symphonic poem is one of his most famous compositions and is often seen as an example of the genre. This work is based on a poem by Alphonse de Lamartine of the same name that explores ideas of fate and destiny. Liszt uses a variety of musical devices to illustrate Lamartine’s poem, including changes in tempo and dynamics, harmonic shifts, and orchestral colour.

Liszt’s use of thematic transformation in Les Préludes is one of the most striking aspects of the work. Thematic transformation is a compositional technique whereby a musical theme is altered or transformed in order to create a distinct idea or mood. In Les Préludes, Liszt uses this technique to great effect, transforming the main theme of destiny into several different musical ideas that represent different aspects of the poem.

Beginning with three notes (C-B-E), the piece is a dreamy introduction. In a thematic transformation, this motif will be repeated throughout the work. Using this single motif, the music moves from a dawn of enchantment to a tumultuous battle to a triumphant ending.

My first experience listening to Liszt’s Les Préludes was incredibly moving. With Liszt’s use of thematic transformation, I could really feel the tension that he had created, although sometimes it was challenging to discern where the main theme was. I really like this piece of music.

References

Les Préludes | work by Liszt (2013). Available at: https://www.britannica.com/topic/Les-Preludes (Accessed: 30 November 2022).

item.title: Listening to Luís de Freitas Branco – Suite Alentejana No. 1
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Luís de Freitas Branco was a Portuguese composer, musicologist, and professor of music who played a pre-eminent part…
item.content:encoded:
Luís de Freitas Branco was a Portuguese composer, musicologist, and professor of music who played a pre-eminent part in developing Portuguese music in the first half of the 20th century. He wrote over 150 pieces of music, including orchestral works, chamber music and works for the stage, as well as songs and choral works. Suite Alentejana No. 1 is one of his most famous works and is known for its energetic rhythms, colourful orchestration and vibrant melodies.

The piece is written for a large orchestra with 3 flutes, 2 oboes, English horn, 2 clarinets, bass clarinet, 2 bassoons, 4 trumpets, 3 trombones, tuba, timpani, bass drum, cymbals, triangle, castanets and harp, as well as strings.

Luís de Freitas Branco’s Suite Alentejana No. 1, written in 1919, is a celebrated work that demonstrates his preference for the Alentejo region of Portugal. Personally, the third and final movement, known as the Fandango, stands out for its vibrant energy and eloquent orchestration. It is written for orchestra with elements of folk music from Alentejo such as a binary-metered rhythm and castanets incorporated into the piece. The form of the piece is tripartite (A-B-A), with an English horn solo leading to a choral section in between two energised sections featuring returning themes. As we close the Fandango brilliantly, the exuberance and vigour of the first section return.

item.content:encoded:
Maria João Pires’ performance was the first I heard. The dynamic range is quite wide and there is a lot of rubato. It seems that she plays faster prior to the louder dynamics and slower prior to the quieter markings. The performance becomes less monotonous and more interesting as a result.

Like Maria João Pires, Rubinstein uses a lot of rubato, especially on the highest notes. In his performance, he sustains high notes subtly to create a more dramatic effect. In spite of the short dynamic range in the Agitato, the last section is intense and played with an astonishing force.

I listened to Nakamura’s live performance. During the performance there was a lot of use of rubato, moving faster and slower several times within a short period of time. The first ornaments are played very slowly, compared to other performances, and she doesn’t completely stop at the fermatas. As a whole, I feel like a lot of creative liberties were taken during the performance regarding speed.

This recording by Lisiecki is the one that follows the score more closely. Particularly the stacatto at the end of the main phrase. It was the only performer I listened to who played stacatto and it opened my eyes to a new perspective. Throughout the piece there is very little rubato nor a lot of variation in dynamics, making it less dramatic than other performances.

Foderova’s performance is very intense. Maybe because it’s a live performance. A lot of that intensity comes from the rubato and some creative liberties she takes with the score, but mainly from her pauses. She uses dramatic pauses, especially at the end of the Agitato, which lasts for almost six seconds.

item.title: Research point 2.4: Performance practice in practice
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Every artistic form that requires performers, such as theatre, cinema, dance, or music, always raises the question: how…
item.content:encoded:
Every artistic form that requires performers, such as theatre, cinema, dance, or music, always raises the question: how personal should a performance be? Should the interpretation of written art be faithful to the author’s intentions? Does it make sense to contextualize old works to the era in which they were performed? Is there a set of rules to follow? If so, does that make a performance authentic? What is authenticity?

There are many questions when it comes to Performance Practice. I won’t be able to answer all of them, but I’ll try to answer “What is Performance Practice?”, “What factors should a performer consider when interpreting a score?” and “What makes a good performance?”.

The field of Performance Practice or Historical Informed Practice studies performance (Rile, 2014), specifically how performance was practised in the past. In general, it focuses on works from the 18th century and earlier that have no contemporary recordings. In order to make an informed interpretation of a piece, a performer should take into account that music reflects the culture of the place where it was composed. In addition to its composer’s personality, it reflects the values of its society at the time the piece was composed and the instruments available.

A successful performance practice involves a number of factors inherent to the music, including sound, physical space, tuning and temperament, articulation, tempo, and dynamics (Duffin, 2017).

Sound, for instance, describes how instruments sounded at the time of composition. Many instruments have changed since then. Some don’t exist anymore, and others weren’t invented until the 18th century (such as the piano). Therefore, when choosing instruments to play, the performer must consider the sound the composer intended.

Dynamic and tempo are also examples. It is usually up to the interpreter to decide what those indications in the scores mean. In terms of tempo, metronomes weren’t invented until the 19th century, so pieces written before that can’t be gauged concretely. In fact, there is some debate about whether Bach’s music has been played faster or slower over time (Niles, 2018). Similarly, dynamics are ambiguous. A forte or piano can mean something different to different performers or even to different venues.

A historically informed performance is also influenced by factors that are extrinsic to music. This includes the social and political context, the piece’s commission, and the venue where it was to be performed. Factors such as these can help determine intrinsic musical characteristics.

In the end, the most influential factor is the personality of the performer, which influences the interpretation of the piece greatly. Without a performer’s interpretation, all performances of a piece would sound the same. It is my belief that most composers would not wish to remove that human trait from a performance. 

All arts are human by definition. As a result, such arts will always feature interpretation, improvisation, adaptation, contextualization, ambition, and imagination. Ultimately, what makes a good performance, and specifically good performance practice, will come down to the performer’s good judgment.

References

Rile, K. (2014) Christopher Hogwood, founder of the ‘historically informed performance …, Jstor. Available at: https://daily.jstor.org/christopher-hogwood-founder-of-the-historically-informed-performance-movement-dies/ (Accessed: November 14, 2022).

Duffin, D.R.W. (2017) Performance Practice: Que me veux-tu?, Dr Ross W Duffin Performance Practice Que me veuxtu Comments. Available at: https://casfaculty.case.edu/ross-duffin/96-2/ (Accessed: November 14, 2022).

Niles, L. (2018) Study: Performances of classical music are getting slower! I mean quicker! wait, what?, Violinist.com. Available at: https://www.violinist.com/blog/laurie/201810/27520/ (Accessed: November 14, 2022).

item.content:encoded:
Sonata in D Major, TWV 44:1 is a piece of Baroque music composed by the German composer Georg Philipp Telemann (1681-1767). It combines elements of concerto and suite genres and is composed for trumpet, strings, and basso continuo. 

Three movements make up the piece, each with its own distinctive character. In Sinfonia Spirituoso, the opening trumpet fanfare presents a lively and energetic start. The second movement, Largo, displays two violins in intimate harmony with the basso continuo. With its lively tempo and energetic tone, the closing movement Vivace brings the piece to a triumphant conclusion.

I found it to be a captivating work of Baroque music with an interesting and multifaceted composition. The opening fanfare immediately captivated me with its bold and triumphant sound.

item.title: Research Point 2.3 – Globalisation
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Some claim that the world is gradually becoming united, that it will grow into a brotherly community as…
item.content:encoded:
Globalisation is “a term that describes a new era of human communication and interconnection across cultural, national, and geographic boundaries” (Beaster-Jones, 2013). In other words, it refers to a growing relationship between culture, economy, and people, with an emphasis on the economic side. In this text, cosmopolitanism and globalisation must be distinguished. The first one is a socioeconomic force that strives to homogenize consumption. The second is a personal attitude towards embracing diversity and humanizing it (Petriglieri, 2016).

A modern concept of globalisation might have started with the Roman Empire, which interconnected the world (part of it, to be precise), leading to easier mobility (Bora & Bonelli, 2019). Globalisation was made truly global around the 16th century when the relationship between countries such as Portugal, Spain, India and China intensified (Flynn & Giraldez, 2007). As transportation became easier, safer, and faster, cultures, thoughts, and rituals clashed more frequently in various aspects of society in the 17th and 18th centuries. Culture and music were not exceptions, as music is inherently social.

Globalisation during the romantic period was caused by three factors. First of all, the decrease in aristocracy patronage broadened audiences and gave the artist more room for experimentation with novel sounds, techniques, and instruments. Secondly, artists became more virtuosic and self-expressive, leading to a fusion of their cultural roots with traditional and local music, creating new sounds. Bartók and Chopin, for instance, are known for incorporating folk songs from their birth countries into their music. Lastly, the mobility of artists. Artists (and audiences) have become less limited by time and space and were able to interact across many locations. Apart from the increase in world fairs and music festivals that attracted worldwide audiences, music tourism and travel allowed artists to experience new cultures and be inspired by them.

As a result of increased globalisation, artists experimented more and audiences were predisposed to exploring different sounds, new formats, and new instruments. This resulted in even broader experimentation during the modernist era, which influenced modern music in the 20th century. If artists and audiences weren’t inclined to merge cultures and experiment with new sounds, genres like blues, jazz, rock, K-pop and reggaeton wouldn’t exist.

Even though society and music have made remarkable advances, there are some concerns about globalisation. A major concern is the loss of individuality. Cultural homogenization is a risk associated with globalisation, and there is a fear that the individuality and identity of a group will be lost in an effort to incorporate other cultural settings (Back, 2012). There is also concern about undue cultural appropriation, which is a more recent concern. In the context of globalisation, cultural appropriation is unavoidable. However, a question arises as to how we can use other cultures’ proprieties and what processes are legitimate so that we can increase contact between cultures (Choufan, 2021).

In my opinion, all advances in technology are preparing society for increased globalisation. With the advent of streaming music platforms, social networks, and cheap travel, it’s more common to see the effects of globalisation, such as multi-country genres (K-Pop) or mixed-background bands (The Foreign Exchange and Superorganism). In the future, globalisation may turn into glocalisation (Roudometof, 2016) in which instead of cultural homogenization, local cultures will adapt global phenomena into their own traditions. This can be seen today, where there is a widening diversity of consumption of Spotify and iTunes in different countries than ever before (Bello & Garcia, 2021).

item.title: Research Point 2.2 – Wagner’s Ring Cycle
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Wagner took around 26 years to complete the Ring Cycle, which consists of four German-language epic music dramas…
item.content:encoded:
Wagner took around 26 years to complete the Ring Cycle, which consists of four German-language epic music dramas lasting about 16 hours. Although the briefing asked for a 500-word essay, I found it challenging to condense such a monumental cycle to that length. The result was a longer text. I watched Opera North’s performance of The Ring Cycle.

“The Nibelungen Myth as Sketch for a Drama” was Wagner’s first prose sketch in 1848, which sparked his interest in the project. When Wagner began writing the poem (the libretto) for Siegfried’s Death (which became Götterdämmerung), he noticed that the heroic Siegfried had to be described in much more detail and clarity. By working backwards, he crafted Siegfried’s heroic youth story. Siegfried’s parentage and the family history of the Wälsungs are told in Die Walküre. Additionally, Wagner wanted to show how Alberich (the Nibelung dwarf) forged the ring of power from the Rhinegold. The story had been written from end to beginning, and now the music would be composed from beginning to end. In November 1874, the final score for The Ring was completed (Hoover, n.d.).

In Wagner’s vision, this cycle would be set at a festival and performed over three days and one evening. Historically, Wagner had been fascinated by Greek tragedy for some time, and the concept of this opera was a logical fit with those ideals (Hoover, n.d.).

Wagner considered this to be not just a musical composition, but an experience. He introduced the term ‘gesamtkunstwerk’, which means “total work of art”, in two essays in 1849: Art and Revolution and The Artwork of the Future. His goal was to reunite the most common forms of art – music, drama, poetry, and staging (Krause, 2020).

During the development of this opera, he developed much larger orchestras, invented new instruments (the Wagner Tuba was created by him), and took the staging to an entirely unprecedented level. In all likelihood, he was the one who pushed for the lights to be turned down and the drama played in the dark to ensure a better viewing experience (Huizenga & Daugert, 2008). His obsessive specifications led him to build a radically redesigned theatre in Bayreuth, Germany. In doing so, he forever changed the landscape of musical theatre.

In terms of music, this cycle is notable for its use of leitmotifs (over sixty in total). While leitmotifs existed before Wagner, he used them creatively, altering keys, upside down, mixing them together, and more (Midgette, 2021). His music became a narrator and participant in the action, instead of just acting as an accompanist.

This led to the idea of a talking orchestra (Midgette, 2021). It was Wagner’s desire for the orchestra to function like the chorus of a Greek tragedy, predicting, showing, and commenting on what happens. This required sixty-four stringed instruments, four times as many wind instruments, and more prominence for the brass section than was common at the time.

All this grandiosity led to an enormous challenge for the singers. In addition to the length of the opera, the greatest challenge for the singers was to make themselves heard over such a powerful orchestra. The technical difficulty of singing these operas has given rise to the term Wagnerian voice: a voice that is substantial, dense in tone, extremely powerful, and ideally evenly balanced throughout.

Personally, I was most impressed by the amount of work Wagner put into The Ring Cycle. The more research I do, the more I realize how innovative and impactful his work was for our music. By using the orchestra as a storyteller, the music feels a lot like a soundtrack for a movie, very similar to what contemporary composers compose for movies today. It is clear now why composers like Korngold cite Wagner as an inspiration (Ross, 2020).

The development of the characters was another thing I liked. There is no clear line between good and evil. All characters have strengths and flaws, akin to Game Of Thrones and less to Lord Of The Rings. This makes them more human (even Gods) and complex, and the music reflects this.

On the negative side, I felt overwhelmed. Too much is happening all the time, with too many leitmotifs, plots, and themes. It’s true that the leitmotifs appear again and again during the operas, but there isn’t much sense of repetition that makes the ears rest from the continuous novelty. There is almost an impression that Wagner wanted to show all of his virtuosity in one work and to develop his ideas as much as possible. However, it’s always a good idea to remember that less is more.

item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In the last few weeks, I’ve been reading the book Dilla Time, about the life of James DeWitt…
item.content:encoded:
In the last few weeks, I’ve been reading the book Dilla Time, about the life of James DeWitt Yancey, better known as J Dilla and Jay Dee. He was an American record producer, drummer, rapper, songwriter, and rapper. It is Dilla’s “drunk”, and “laid back” time-feel that makes his work unique and difficult to interpret, define, or translate. His production style has inspired some of the world’s most renowned pop, hip-hop, and jazz musicians — achieved, in part, because he didn’t quantize his music (Fitzpatrick, 2011).

While I don’t listen to a lot of hip-hop, I was intrigued by his stories and how he blew everyone away with his eccentric rhythms, so I decided to check out some of the music he produced or composed (Stadnicki, 2017). My favourite was Running by The Pharcyde, released in 1995.

It begins with a simple maracas sample from James Moody, followed by acoustic guitar from Luiz Bonfá. As I listen to these samples, I realize that the tempo is not always right. I start to understand why people talk about J Dilla when the drums start playing. It seems like the kick drum is rushing (perhaps running?) while the snare is dragging after the hi-hats. This results in strangely relaxed music, with an endless forward motion.

These kinds of not quantized drum sounds are somehow normal nowadays and explored by a lot of musicians, but I can imagine how refreshing it was to listen to such a relaxed and “humanized” beat after listening to so much on-tempo electronic music from the late ’80s and early ’90s.

item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: “Letter from Home” is a composition by American composer Aaron Copland, written in 1944 and commissioned as a…
item.content:encoded:
“Letter from Home” is a composition by American composer Aaron Copland, written in 1944 and commissioned as a patriotic work by Paul Whiteman for his Radio Hall of Fame Orchestra. The piece is a reflection on the experiences of soldiers returning home from war, and the changes that they have undergone during their time away. The piece is written in the style of a letter from a soldier to his family and conveys the bittersweet emotions of coming home after having seen the horrors of war.

The piece begins with a sombre, reflective melody, as the soldier reflects on his experiences and considers the changes that have taken place in his life since departing. The music slowly builds to a more upbeat, hopeful tone, as the soldier finds comfort in the thought of being reunited with his family and friends. The piece ends with a triumphant, joyous melody, as the soldier celebrates the joy of being home. The instrumentation is sparse and haunting, evoking a sense of loneliness and longing.

Ultimately, “Letter from Home” is a powerful and poignant tribute to the soldiers who have sacrificed so much for their country. Through its emotional intensity and evocative musical language, Copland captures the complex emotions of a soldier returning home.

Keith Jarrett is a celebrated American jazz musician and composer. He has been active since the 1960s and has released several acclaimed albums, such as My Song, which came out in 1978. His music often features a sublime simplicity and directness that has made it a favorite among jazz enthusiasts.

The title track of Keith Jarrett’s 1978 album, My Song, is a timeless piece featuring the collaborative efforts of the European Quartet. The melody is introduced by a pensive piano movement that is soon joined by Jan Garabek’s saxophone and Jon Christensen’s percussion, which uses shakers and cymbals to create a soft and muted backdrop. Over the years, My Song has become a popular standard among jazz musicians, with Pat Metheny being one of its most notable interpreters.

item.title: Research point 2.1: Hector Berlioz – Harold en Italie
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Symphonie Fantastique, one of Hector Berlioz’s most well-known compositions, was composed in 1830. After winning the Prix de…
item.content:encoded:
Click here to see the briefing

Write around 400 words on your impression of the score and music. Among other things consider:

  1. To what extent do you find the composition depicts its programme?
  2. What do you find extraordinary?
  3. What catches your eye or your ear?
  4. How is the solo viola used?

Symphonie Fantastique, one of Hector Berlioz’s most well-known compositions, was composed in 1830. After winning the Prix de Rome, the composer spent fifteen months in Italy between 1831 and 1832, and this experience is especially evident in Harold in Italy. Berlioz preferred the Abruzzi mountains over the academy’s environment, concerts, and operas in Rome (Bynog et al., 2021).

After Paganini’s commission of Harold in Italy, Berlioz finished it in 1834, not only recalling his experience in Italy as an inspiration for the programmatic structure of this symphony but also drawing inspiration from Lord Byron’s popular poem Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage. This resulted in Berlioz utilizing descriptive titles for each movement and the corresponding programmatic nature of the music since he was aiming for writing “a musical impression of the archetypal romantic hero” (Clements, 2001):

  • Harold in the mountains
  • Procession of the Pilgrims Singing Their Evening Prayer
  • Serenade
  • The Orgy of the Brigands

Unifying all these movements is the solo instrument: the viola. In his plan, Berlioz envisaged “a series of orchestral scenes in which the viola would be involved […] like an actual person, retaining the same character throughout”. That character would be “a melancholy dreamer in the style of Byron’s Childe Harold” (Deller, 2019).

The most interesting thing is that, facing a plan like this, a composer would be compelled to write strong, loud and bold viola lines in every movement, making the instrument and the player shine. But Berlioz took another approach. In order to create a character like Harold, he made the viola gentle, shy, and quiet. It is the orchestra that can sometimes be loud, rough, and strong.

I was struck by the instruction to play the viola as softly as possible – barely audible. This paradoxically draws more attention to the instrument. A very quiet performance requires an effort on the part of the audience to be able to hear it. The viola player, however, needs to be highly skilled, since it is more difficult to play loudly than softly. For the sound intensity to be maintained along the bow’s full length, the performer’s stance must be firmly grounded with solid shoulders and right arm stability (Bathurst, 2016).

This piece was written in the aftermath of the French Revolution and the Napoleonic devastation and trauma, when society was deciding whether to be ruled by a charismatic leader of a totalitarian or by a humane, humble and compassionate leader (Bathurst, 2016). As a humanitarian (Klein, 1969), I believe Berlioz used the viola as a symbol of the latter, being subtle and quiet and allowing the orchestra to shine when necessary, rather than being the solo instrument that always takes center stage. Paganini might not have realized this when he read the score, but after hearing it and watching the viola’s role, he understood.

Beethoven dead there was no one but Berlioz who could bring him back to life; and I who have experienced your divine compositions worthy of a genius such as yours, believe it is my duty to beg you to be willing to accept as a sign of my homage 20,000 francs.

Letter from Paganini to Berlioz

item.title: Listening to Jörg Widmann – Viola Concerto
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: It was while researching Berlioz’s Harold in Italy that I came across an article by French violist Antoine…
item.content:encoded:
It was while researching Berlioz’s Harold in Italy that I came across an article by French violist Antoine Tamestit. This article stated, in 2015, when he played Harold with John Eliot for the first time, he told German composer Jörg Widmann how delighted he was with the piece. Therefore, Widmann composed a viola concerto filled with narration, journeys and interactions with multiple orchestral instruments.

Based on this description, I decided to watch Tamestit’s performance with the Frankfurt Radio Symphony conducted by Andrés Orozco-Estrada.

My overall reaction was one of awe and I still don’t know if I liked it or not. However, I believe that was the purpose of this concerto. In one interview, Tamestit explains that this piece is intended to disorient the listener (Todes, 2021). While I sometimes understood what the composer was saying, other times I felt disoriented and I wondered if it wasn’t just too much theatrical for show’s sake.

In the same interview, Tamestit talks about how the instrumentation is unusual. This concerto, for instance, requires the soloist to scream throughout and requires the pianist to hold a whiskey glass.

I wasn’t expecting such a theatrical performance with such an emphasis on the viola soloist. But as an homage or follow-up to Berlioz’s symphony, Widmann seemed to want to keep the viola at the center of this performance.

The viola is the focus of this piece, for me. As it takes the listener through the viola’s different sounds, blending and clashing with other instruments, and finding its place within the orchestra.

Berlioz’s symphony and this concerto have many connections, but for me, the biggest one is the instrument’s representation. In Harold in Italy, the viola embodied Harold, here the instrument symbolized itself. As I realized, Widmann attempted to meta-characterize the viola. And that was a brilliant idea.

References

Todes, A. (2021) ‘it is in my blood’: Antoine Tamestit on Jörg Widmann’s Viola Concerto, London Symphony Orchestra. Available at: https://lso.co.uk/whats-on/alwaysplaying/read/1473-it-is-in-my-blood-antoine-tamestit-on-jorg-widmann-s-viola-concerto.html (Accessed: October 19, 2022).

item.title: Assignment 1 – Part 2
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: The more constraints one imposes, the more one frees one’s self… Igor Stravinsky Upon reading Stravinsky’s quote, I…
item.content:encoded:
Click to read the briefing

The 20th Century composer Igor Stravinsky (1882-1971), who himself was a connoisseur of music from previous periods, gave this quote as part of a series of lectures he gave at Harvard University in 1939. Drawing on your own thoughts and experience, and clearly referring to the four points below as well as developing ideas of your own, write 500 words discussing Stravinsky’s phrase from the point of view of rules in music. Try to explore your ideas as far as you can – especially the ones that are particularly important to you.

  • Did you find strategies to cope with the rules outlined in this chapter?
  • What steps could you take to learn writing 16th Century counterpoint?
  • What qualities do you think the strictness of 16th Century compositional technique brings to the music?
  • Discuss the value of rules in composing and performing music.

Reflection

Upon reading Stravinsky’s quote, I understood it quite intuitively. Due to my advertising background, most of the creative challenges I faced had constraints, so this subject is dear to me. In my experience, it was the “open challenges,” those without boundaries or limitations, that were the hardest to overcome.

Considering I could explore the theme more, the 500-word limit felt a bit short to me. There is a lot to discuss about rules’ effectiveness, human bodies and instruments as extrinsic limitations, rules’ roles in AI music composition, and if there is a right amount of restriction that promotes creativity. Nevertheless, I realized that a 500-word essay about constraints needs a constraint, so I summarized my main points.

Throughout this essay, the word “constraint” can take on many forms, such as “rule”, “limit”, or “boundary”. In most cases, however, the meaning remains the same. A set of extrinsic and intrinsic restraints that an artist is confronted with when using a creative medium.

Essay

In this quote, apart from playing with paradoxical word use, Stravinsky was saying that all creativity revolves around solving problems (Harnad et al., 2008). I believe he was arguing that for creativity to reach its full potential, there must be some tension that calls for resolution. Many artists, including Mozart (Blanning, 2016), Frank Gehry (Hereld, 2013), and John Stweart (NPR, 2015), have defended the same position. Constraints and problems are essential for artists so that they can find solutions that will produce knowledge.

What artists develop within these limitations and rules depends on their goals and skills. Beethoven broke them (Page, 2019). Gesualdo bent them (Ross, 2011). John Cage created new ones (Savenko, 2021). However, one thing unites them all. Each of them mastered the rules before creating beyond them.

Even when one considers musical genres in addition to musicians, it becomes apparent that they too need rules. New musical genres are created when “socially accepted rules” are set over the traditional ones (Fabbri, 1980). There is always a cycle: established rules are mastered; then they are questioned; then new rules are developed.

This was evident when monophonic masses were replaced by polyphonic ones. It was a breaking of the rules of a single melodic line that led to the establishment of new rules by the church at the Trent Council and mastered by Palestrina (Monson, 2002). During the 16th Century, these formal rules led to a strictness in compositional technique, which ultimately led to not only a controlled, contemplative, and accessible sound, but also one that was predictable and standardized. By no means am I arguing that the rules were demeaning the music, but they were purely a necessity for the Church to standardize music during the Renaissance (Mock, 2017), which was a time of profound creative and cultural shifts.

To assist composers in learning these contrapuntal compositional techniques of the 16th Century, Johann-Joseph Fux authored in 1725 the Gradus ad Parnassum, during a time when composers refused “to be bound by any rules or principles” (Fux et al., 1971). They are known as species counterpoint and have been a part of the learning of Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn (Norman, nd) and my own learning as well.

To learn and implement these rules, I found it most helpful to understand the “why” behind them. For example, understanding why consecutive fifths and octaves, and unison passages can render the music too dull and boring makes it easier to remember than simply telling me “do not use successive fifths and octaves, or unison passages”. As well as this, I relied on the progressive learning method, where one learns by doing (Kennedy, 2019). This made learning easier by increasing the difficulty one step at a time and letting my mind become accustomed to the rules as I progressed.

Ultimately, the rules and constraints proved to be beneficial to me, as they helped me learn different harmonization and melodic concepts, and proved effective since I was able to compose much faster than I would without them. They also proved useful in helping me become more creative as I learned to solve some musical problems and maybe even come up with new ones in the future.

item.content:encoded:
On the Academic Music Discord server, someone posted a video about Omar Thomas, a composer I had never heard of before.

A composer, arranger and educator, Omar Thomas was born in Brooklyn, N.Y., in 1984. His parents are Guyanese, and he moved to Boston in 2006 to pursue a Master of Music degree at New England Conservatory.

A piece written for a wind ensemble, Piano and Drum Set, Come Sunday celebrates the Hammond organ’s central role in black worship. The second movement, Shout!, is an energetic celebration of gospel, jazz and blues, which shows influences from Duke Wellington and Charles Mingus as well as traditional church singing.

In listening to Shout!, I was surprised at how energetic it was after the slow and melodic first movement. There was an instant connection for me to the rhythm of this piece, marked by brass, bass, and drums, with the repetitive woodwinds in a high register adding the necessary tension.

As I listened to this piece, I was reminded of 70s funk horns and woodwinds. That’s what makes this piece so beautiful. Mixing genres and decades, creating a fresh and joyful time for the listener and for the players.

Since I am unfamiliar with much of the new classical music, I am enjoying this opportunity to listen to contemporary composers. At the same time that I study traditional techniques, I believe this will facilitate me in understanding the paths new composers are taking.

First Species

Using the tips from the First Species, I created a melodic line that was always consonant and moved mostly in contrary motion.

Second Species

My greatest struggle came in bars 3 and 4, where I was trying to connect the melody with the given D in bar 4. Keeping with the instructions to make leaps inside the bar, I decided to leap from B to E in bar 3.

Third Species

Due to the pre-given patterns in bar 4 (nota cambiata pattern) and bar 6 (double neighbour pattern) in the third species, I started this species backwards in bar 6. Even with the given patterns, I tried to maintain a fluid melodic line with no big leaps, and always respected the previous species’ guidelines.

Fourth Species

Since the suspension must be resolved downwards and in consonance with the upbeat, I found this one to be the easiest species. 

Fifth Species

As compared to the previous species, the fifth one took me a lot lI wasn’t sure how the bass and alto should harmonize with the tenor while imitating each other. Jacob Gran’s video helped me realize we should make the three-voice counterpoint as harmonically complete as possible. Thus, for example, in bar 3, the bass is supposed to imitate the tenor by going from D to F, but that would be dissonant. The right choice is E since it makes a C major triad.

item.content:encoded:
In another Spotify discovery, I listened to a piece that I had never heard before. My attention was immediately captured when a traditional drum kit entered playing a classic hip-hop pattern in the first 16 seconds.

Rock the Violin in Rhapsody. Hip-Hop is the first movement of the Violin Concerto “Rhapsody & Fantasy” by Eldbjørg Hemsing and Tan Dun. Hemsing is one of the best violinists in Norway, while Tan Dun is one of the most renowned conductors and composers that lives in New York but was born in China.

Having found a score for this concerto, I discovered that it includes a strong percussion section with five players, in addition to woodwinds, brass, and strings. It’s easy to hear the rhythm throughout this piece since it’s very heavy on it.

My favourite aspect of the piece was the constant play between rhythmic, hip-hop ambient and the almost wild solo violin. The play kept the piece alive and prevented it from becoming monotonous, which could happen with a simple hip-hop beat.

As described by Xenia Hanusiak in her article, the composer calls this Rhapsody and Fantasia “the perfect result” of his thirty-five years of living in New York. It is one of the most interesting pieces I have heard in a while due to its combination of street sound rhythm, classical Chinese instruments, and a harsh nordic violin.

item.content:encoded:
Exercise 1.2: First species

In this exercise I followed the tip given by the briefing and worked backwards, starting from the last bar. I followed the tip of if the cantus rises from the leading note to the tonic, then the free part falls from the second degree to the octave. From there, I went to the first bar and add an octave. Between bars 2 and 6 I mostly worked stepwise, with a 6th, 3rd, 3rd, 6th, and 6th. I then noticed a leap to get from bar 6 to 7, which didn’t sound perfect but it didn’t sound bad either.

In the end, when I listened to it, I found it very dull. Probably because of the mostly stepwise motion and some parallel motion, it sounded predictable. So, I decided to give it another try and start with a 5th.

I left the last two bars, erased all the rest and started with a C. From there I tried to add some contrary motion with a 3rd, 6th, 6th, 3rd and 6th. From bar 6 to 7 there’s the same leap as the previous try, but this time it sounded better. Probably because from bar 5 to 6 there is a contrary motion, or because it comes from a 3rd to 6th instead of a 6th to 6th. I’m not really sure.

When I checked the sample solution I was surprised to see that my second try is exactly the same as the solution. I believe this must be because there’s a much more finite option with just 3rds and 6ths, but I was pleased to know that my effort to make a second try got me closer to what is expected from this exercise.

Exercise 1.3: Second species

I started this exercise as the previous one, writing the last two bars first and then moving from the first bar until the cadence.

In this case, I followed the tip of leaving the first downbeat with a rest to establish a pulse and started the counterpoint with an octave. From there I wrote all downbeats with consonants and the upbeats I used as passing notes, except in bar 5 because I felt that the top melody needed a higher note to get to the climax.

Exercise 1.4: Fourth species

This exercise was different because some of the notes of the species melody were given. In this case it starts with a 5th that turns into a dissonance with a 4th wich I resolved down one step into a consonant 3rd. The next note was also given and I raised the melody to a 6th that suspends into a dissonant 7th and is resolved to a 6th that leads to raise one step to the final octave.

This exercise was similar to the previous one, but this time with several consecutive suspensions. With the notes given, I developed the species melody following the tips of the Fourth Species and previous ones. For example, started in an octave, kept the range within the octave above, one climax only, the dissonance is resolved on step down on the weak beat and the cadence with contrary motion by step. In the end, one thing I noticed is that the species melody is very predictable between bars 5 and 8, because the P-D-R is always 4th to 3rd. I tried to change this but, with the given notes, it was impossible. I later checked the sample solution and it was the same, so I suppose it’s the only way to complete this exercise.

Exercise 1.5: Imitative counterpoint

Initially, I had difficulty understanding the exercise. It didn’t make sense to me how the motive could fit in the blank spaces. Once you understood how it worked, it became an intuitive exercise. The only thing I couldn’t figure out was how to add the dash in the lyrics in Sibelius so it appears only in the beat, rather than randomly in the bar, as it appears below. 

It was the first time a third voice was added to the exercises. There was no change in the challenge: imitative counterpoint. I found this one easier than the previous one, despite the new voice’s increased challenge. The gaps only allowed space for imitation of the motive, so I was able to write the motive easily and then check for any counterpoint errors.

item.title: Listening to Max Bruch – Concerto for Clarinet & Viola, Op. 88: I. Andante Con Moto
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Max Bruch (1838-1920) is a well-known prolific German composer. During his long career, he taught, conducted, and composed.…
item.content:encoded:
Max Bruch (1838-1920) is a well-known prolific German composer. During his long career, he taught, conducted, and composed. In 1911, Bruch composed the Double Concerto in E minor, Op.88. This piece was composed for his son Max Felix Bruch, who was a first-class clarinettist.

A review of Bruch’s Double Concerto Op.88 premiere, published in Allgemeine Musikzeitung Zeitung No. 40 (1913), called it “harmless,” “weak,” and “uninteresting” (Fifield, 1988).

Initially, I was intrigued by the strange combination of clarinet and viola in this Double Concerto. My impression after listening to this piece is that both instruments can very well mimic human timbres. As a result, the solo instruments have a lyrical and melodic sound. As the two solo instruments weave melodies around each other, the orchestra provides a stable backdrop.

The first movement of this work presents Bruch’s two solo instruments in a rather dramatic manner. In the beginning, the solo viola is boldly introduced, followed by the clarinet. Throughout the entire movement, it feels as if both instruments are having an intimate conversation.

Upon hearing this movement, I felt as if there was nothing shocking and nothing wrong, at least to my ears. In addition to being a conservative, Bruch was opposed to ‘modern madness’ and ‘modernists’ like Strauss, Reger, and Debussy (the latter he termed an ‘unqualified scribbler’). As a whole, I enjoyed this piece, especially the interplay between the two solo instruments.

References

Fifield, C. (1988) Max Bruch his life and works. London: Gollancz.

Viola and clarinet concerto and other viola compositions by Bruch (no date) Viola in Music.com. Available at: http://www.viola-in-music.com/viola-and-clarinet-concerto.html .

item.title: Research point 1.1: The Mass
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: As important as the madrigal and chanson, the polyphonic setting of the Catholic Mass was the most significant genre…
item.content:encoded:
As important as the madrigal and chanson, the polyphonic setting of the Catholic Mass was the most significant genre during the Renaissance. Many of the greatest compositions of music have been influenced by musical settings of the Mass.

What makes a Mass?

Besides being a religious ceremony, a mass is also a genre of music. The mass, as a ceremony, is a rite of the Roman Catholic church. It is divided into three parts: introductory rites, the liturgy of the word, and the eucharistic liturgy. During this ceremony, the congregation receives bread and wine reenacting the last supper (Keep It Classical, 2021).

Several parts of the liturgy are either spoken, intoned or sung. Some of them, called Proper, vary according to where we are in the liturgical calendar, while others, called Ordinary, remain the same.

Mass as a musical genre is made up of five movements: Kyrie, Gloria, Credo, Sanctus, and Anus Dei sung by the choir during the Ordinary. 

Creating musical continuity among all these different sections was the greatest formal challenge. Several solutions were developed, including repeating the same plainchant (cantus firmus) throughout. This was done well by talented Mass composers. Throughout every section, the cantus firmus is not repeated note-for-note but rather fragmented into long, sustained notes sung by the tenor.

Masses in the Renaissance were generally divided into two categories: those composed based on previously composed materials and those without.

The evolution of the Masses

In my research, I have found that most literature focuses on the Mass during the Renaissance period, leaving only minimal attention to the Middle Ages and even less for the following centuries. It may be due to a more uniform unity in style during the Renaissance, pushed by the church. A prominent example is Pope Gregorious’ role in bringing together diverse chants into an orderly and uniform whole for the western region of the Church to use. Similarly, the Council of Trent called for clearer texts, simpler polyphony, and fewer melismas later on (Monson, 2002).

Before 1400

The Roman Catholic Church was the only institution that could educate the populace to become literate and enforce standards of faith and morality. This was due to the barbaric invasion and collapse of the Roman Empire. This institution stood against the grit and dereliction of the Dark Ages. Throughout Western Europe, the Church played a critical role in preserving and transmitting Christian culture, which led to music composition and performance practices. Medieval music had the function of enhancing the liturgy and creating a mood of peace, which could be achieved by singing monophonic plainchant. 

Middle Ages Gregorian masses were sung monophonically in unison, with a focus on the Proper. A famous example of the first complete setting of the Ordinary of the Mass dates from the 14th century, Guillaume de Machaut’s La Messe de Nostre Dame.

Renaissance

Between 1400 and 1600 was the main period of Mass composition, when the Mass took on its present meaning of a polyphonic setting of the entire Mass Ordinary.  Renaissance composers regarded the Ordinary Mass as the equivalent of 18th-century composers’ symphonies, or 19th-century composers’ operas: the ultimate test of their talents and creativity. In this period, composers within the area of sacred music focused primarily on the forms of mass, with their multiple-movement format offering large-scale structure opportunities (Apel, 2000).

After 1600

The importance of Mass composition declined after 1600. In spite of this, there were developments such as huge choirs of 32 and 48 parts (Orazio Benevoli, 1605-72) and the use of orchestras, leading to Bach’s B-minor Mass (1733-38) (Apel, 2000).

The mass evolved towards secularization in the 18th and 19th centuries with works by Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, Liszt and Bruckner.

The 20th and 21st centuries saw composers write masses in a variety of styles, forms, and functions that were even more diverse than before (e.g. Vaughan Williams, Stravinsky, Duruflé, Britten, Rutter, Sato).

Reflection about the connection of music with religion

Write a brief article of around 500 words in your listening log about the connection of music with religion. Mix in your personal views with what you have discovered through research.

As a result of my research, it’s quite clear that music and religion have always been closely intertwined, and their impact on who we are today is massive. As a matter of fact, some advocates argue that in place of agriculture and farming, music and religion would be the main drivers of sedentary behavior for humans (Spitzer, 2021).

But which came first? Music or religion? I could not find anyone who could answer this question. This leaves me believing that since humans first beat sticks repeatedly against rocks, there has been a sense of spirituality as well as divinity. This, along with the quote I used to begin this text, sum up what I believe and is supported by my research: religion and music are so closely related that it’s difficult not to believe they are one and the same. 500 words are too few for me to express my view, but I’ll try to summarize it into three points.

Both religion and music alter the state of mind

According to Gilbert Rouget, music can induce two types of altered state of consciousness (ASC) across all cultures, ‘trance’ (solitude, silence, immobility, sensory) and ‘ecstasy’ (movement, noise, sociable) (Rouget, 1985). The same applies to religion. When dancing for a long period of time, the body suffers from fatigue, hyperventilation, hypoglycaemia, and hypoglycaemia, leading to hallucinations. Overheating at raves releases endogenous opiates. When you fast and sleep less before a rave, the driving rhythms are amplified. There has been evidence of all these effects in religious traditions, from Pentecostal churches in the American Deep South to Sufi dervishes (Spitzer, 2021).

Both religion and music are based on routines

Religion is embedded in everyday life, and it shouldn’t come as a surprise. One of the best examples is when John Cage asked someone about their religion while in Japan. The answer was dance. Japanese practice Buddhist and Shinto rituals, but they don’t go to church or temple on a regular basis. It is so integrated into the culture that it appears in daily gestures and routines, undisturbed by ordinary life (Byrne, 2017). The same with music. A social organization is marked by song at nearly every point in the lives of communities, according to ethnomusicologist Alan P. Merriam—birth songs, lullabies, naming songs, toilet-training songs, puberty songs, greetings, love songs, marriage songs, clan songs, and funeral songs.

Both religion and music connect people

People turn to religion and music during hard times. There is a search for hope, connection, and optimism among people. Because of its certainty, religious thought is particularly conducive to optimism. In addition, Michael Hogg asserts that feeling closely connected with others leads to feelings of more security, confidence, and certainty about what to expect in the social world as a result (Hogg, 2003). The same happens with music. There is no doubt that music helps us feel hopeful and secure in times of uncertainty, such as with shows like Live Aid, The Concert For New York City or Concert For Bangladesh.

When I attended Kendirck Lamar’s concert last time, I wasn’t sure if I was watching a music concert or a worship service. As I looked at other people at the concert, they all seemed mentally altered, either in a trance or ecstatic state. They were making the same moves and singing the same lyrics. Most importantly, they all seemed connected and hopeful.

Was this music or religion?

References

Keep It Classical, 2021. Different Types of Renaissance Masses – How to Tell Each Mass Type Apart, YouTube. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yNn344lbWPM [Accessed September 27, 2022].

Monson, C.A., 2002. The Council of Trent Revisited. Journal of the American Musicological Society, 55(1), pp.1–37.

Apel, W., 2000. Mass. In Harvard Dictionary of Music. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University.

Byrne, D., 2017. How music works, New York: Three Rivers Press.

item.content:encoded:
During my research, I listened to masses from different periods of history, but my focus was exclusively on the Kyrie.

Machaut: Messe de Nostra Dame: Kyrie (1365)
(Guillaume & Royllart, 2016)

This Ordinary of the Mass composed before 1365 is considered the earliest complete setting attributable to any single composer. The Kyrie is written in polyphony for four voices and features lots of melismas. This piece is divided into three sections, each with the same structure: polyphony – plainchant – polyphony. As far as the sound quality is concerned, I found it to be very diverse, with each voice having its own distinct characteristics, but working together to create a pleasing whole.

Victoria: Missa O magnum mysterium: Kyrie (1592)
(Smith & de, 1997)

O magnum mysterium (published in 1572) became the basis for Victoria’s 1592 Mass for a four-part choir. Since this short Kyrie is in imitation polyphonic texture, the voices do not appear to have any real distinctive characteristic, but rather blend together to achieve a more common sound.

Bach: Mass in B minor: Kyrie I (1749)
(Herreweghe, 2011)

Compared to my previous two masses, this is a big difference. This work is for five voices with instrumental accompaniment, which makes a completely different sound from choral masses without accompaniment. It is evident that Bach is stepping up the masses from church music to concert music, making them suitable for a concert hall. In this polyphonic Kyrie, what I found most interesting is the way, from bar 30, the sound never settles until the last bar. The tension and expectation lasts for about 5 minutes.

Mozart: Great Mass in C minor K.427: Kyrie (1783)
(Bernstein et al., 1991)

After listening to it, I understand why it is considered one of Mozart’s greatest works. It is a magnificent composition for two soprano soloists, a tenor and a bass, a double chorus and a large orchestra. Similarly to Bach’s mass, Mozart wanted to make the experience more performance and entertainment-based, instead of contemplative and solemn. For me, the most appealing part of this Kyrie is the soprano solo, particularly when it reaches a low Ab and jumps two octaves higher in the following measure.

Beethoven: Mass in C Major, Op.86:I. Kyrie (1807)
(Kampen, K.V. et al., 2005)

Compared to the previous masses I had listened to, the texture of this Kyrie surprised me. In my opinion, Beethoven decided to compose a homophonic-based mass that heavily relied on the choir. Throughout, there is an intriguing play of dynamics, swaying up and down and conveying different emotions in a short space of time, with some parts with breathtaking soaring voices. A note about Gloria in excelsis Deo, which is one of my favourite versions I’ve heard.

Bruckner: Mass in E minor: Kyrie (1866)
(Parkman, 2019)

It’s a mass that feels like a travel back in time, stripped of all instrumental accompaniment and focusing primarily on choral. The combination of choir and brass in this Kyrie really caught my attention. This created a very dramatic and mournful sound. But I was most impressed by the use of silences and the absence of sound in some parts, which gave this piece a huge hollowness.

item.title: Listening to José Almarcha – Casa del Gallego
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: As usual, my Spotify is on shuffle and today I heard some flamenco, which I am not particularly…
item.content:encoded:
As usual, my Spotify is on shuffle and today I heard some flamenco, which I am not particularly familiar with, but enjoy listening to occasionally. This song caught my attention, so I listened carefully.

Originally from Ciudad Real, José Almarcha is an outstanding guitarist and composer. As a student of flamenco at the Córdoba Conservatory of Music, José studied with flamenco masters including Paco Serrano and Niño de Pura. A number of dancers have been accompanied by him, including Olga Pericet, Marco Flores, and Antonio Canales. His albums have received excellent reviews and he has been hailed as one of Spain’s most promising flamenco guitarists.

The singer recently released Casa del Gallego, which is a farruca, a dance-centric style of flamenco characterized by sombre virtuosity, aggressive footwork, and dramatic tempo changes. 

In this song, the melody is introduced by a flamenco guitar riff, but a few seconds into the song, there’s a surprise: a trombone with a delay effect. Not a typical flamenco sound and a hint to the listener that this probably isn’t a traditional flamenco but yes, a modern view of the style.

Enters the piano a few seconds later. With the trombone on the bottom, the piano on top with high notes, and the flamenco guitar in the middle, the three instruments make a beautiful sonic sandwich.

A mellow melody is gradually introduced by the trio, along with occasional cymbal sounds. Still, the strumming and tapping of guitars always have a slight tension to them. Suddenly, the tension is released as the full band enters, with a Latin rhythm recognizable as flamenco, accompanied by a shoe-tapping sound, along with another surprise: an electric guitar. There is a clash between traditional and modern sounds in the music now, and I find it very appealing.

As the song continues, tension is built and released with more and more shoe tapping and stomping until the apotheosis.

It was very interesting to see how flamenco is approached in a new way. It was entertaining to watch the piece’s sudden changes in sound dynamics that are intended to be interpreted by a dancer and add drama to the performance.

item.title: Exercise 1.1 – Palestrina’s Kyrie from Missa Brevis
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: A master of contrapuntal composition, Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina composed 105 masses and 250 motets in the Italian…
item.content:encoded:
A master of contrapuntal composition, Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina composed 105 masses and 250 motets in the Italian Renaissance. A significant figure in the development of polyphony, he represented the conservatism of the 16th century on the subject of church music.

Though it is widely believed that Palestrina saved polyphony by himself, it is a myth that is widely accepted, although it is also true that the Council of Trent (1545-1563) stressed the importance of musical clarity and Palestrina himself advocated it (Monson, 2002).

Palestrina’s Missa Brevis (Short Mass) was first published in 1570 and is considered one of his most famous works. There are four voices in the Kyrie (Cantus, Altus, Tenor, and Bassus). With the exception of a brief homophonic section at the end of the second Kyrie, the texture is almost exclusively polyphonic. With a gentle melodic line and simple harmony, this piece stays in F major with only occasional chromatic changes, creating a restful, calm atmosphere.

Exercise 1.1

Listen to a recording of the Kyrie from Palestrina’s Missa Brevis and follow with a score.
Read the following comments about features of the music, and note an instance where each occurs in the score. You may find it to be most effective if you mark each occurrence onto a printout of the score or annotate a pdf of it electronically. Keep your annotations for reference later.

  • The entry of each vocal part is in imitation.
  • The texture is polyphonic – consisting of several independently moving, though coordinated, vocal parts.
  • The melody lines themselves move smoothly – mainly flowing by step with occasional leaps but then often turning back and returning to where they came from, or nearby.
  • Each part rises and falls, helping to create a sense of direction but with no single part assuming dominance over the others.
  • The ranges of the individual voice parts lie mainly within an octave and there is a general sense of balance to the individual melodic lines. They rise and fall in about equal measure, exploring the full range of the voice evenly.
  • The words are repeated and are clearly audible. The words overlap, each part at times following, at times leading, to create the musical texture.
The entry of each vocal part is in imitation.

In yellow, I highlighted the parts where the voices imitate one another closely.

The texture is polyphonic – consisting of several independently moving, though coordinated, vocal parts.

There is a stronger sense of polyphony in bars 28-31 (highlighted in red), where all voices move independently.

The melody lines themselves move smoothly – mainly flowing by step with occasional leaps but then often turning back and returning to where they came from, or nearby.

Green highlights passages where the voices move almost exclusively by step. Alto jumps down to D in bar 47, but it quickly returns to upper G.

Each part rises and falls, helping to create a sense of direction but with no single part assuming dominance over the others.

The blue lines, bars 11-14, indicate the rise and fall of each melody, showing some contrary motion, but with no particular voice dominating.

The ranges of the individual voice parts lie mainly within an octave and there is a general sense of balance to the individual melodic lines. They rise and fall in about equal measure, exploring the full range of the voice evenly.

The voices are all within one octave, except Bass and Cantus, which are two tones down, A2 and D4, respectively, although they go there quite uncommonly.

Bass C4 – A2
Tenor F4-F3
Alto B4 – B3
Cantus F5 – D4

The words are repeated and are clearly audible. The words overlap, each part at times following, at times leading, to create the musical texture.

Pink highlights parts where words are repeated either asynchronously, bars 20-27, or simultaneously, bars 56-58.

item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Claudio Monteverdi (1567–1643) Monteverdi was an Italian composer, violinist, singer, and priest. He is often considered a revolutionary…
item.content:encoded:
Claudio Monteverdi (1567–1643)

Monteverdi was an Italian composer, violinist, singer, and priest. He is often considered a revolutionary who marked the transition from Renaissance to Baroque music.

Until the age of forty, Monteverdi worked primarily on madrigals, composing a total of nine books. In about four years, Monteverdi completed his first book of twenty-one madrigals for five voices. Overall, the first eight madrigals show the massive development from Renaissance polyphonic to baroque monodic styles.

He wrote L’Orfeo, one of the earliest operas in the history of music, an innovative work that remains a part of today’s orchestra’s repertoire. Additionally, he has written sacred music.

Orlando di Lasso (1532 – 1594)

Lasso was a Franco-Flemish composer. With more than two thousand compositions to his credit, he was a prolific and versatile author. This collection includes all genres of his day, secular and sacred, including the mass, secular chanson in several languages, Latin motets, hymns, and madrigals. When he held the position of Kapellmeister at the Munich court, at the end of his life, he cultivated sacred music with a special dedication.

He is considered the chief representative of the mature polyphonic style of the Netherlands school, along with Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina. At the end of the 16th century, he was one of the most famous and influential musicians in Europe.

Regarding his madrigals, which he penned while living in Rome, his style was clear and concise, and his tunes were memorable.

Comparison between Orlando di Lasso’s Matona, mia cara and Claudio Monteverdi’s Ah, Dolente Partita

The main reason I chose to compare these two madrigals is their contrasting themes. Lasso’s one is a jovial, lighthearted, and almost mocking monologue between a German soldier and a supposedly Italian woman. Contrary to Monteverdi, his lament is a sombre recognition of death in late life.

From the very beginning, these contrasting themes are evident. Matona, mia cara begins with all four voices in an F Major chord and in a fast tempo. The song develops with a mostly homophonic texture and a very marked rhythm, especially in the “Don, don, don” section. 

Ah, Dolente partita opens with only two voices in unison, singing a long, high E. The two voices stay in unison until bar 4 when they drift apart. As a result, it sounds very sorrowful and enigmatic. As the other voices enter, they do so timidly and not simultaneously. Only in bar 15 do all five voices sing together. However, just after that, in bar 16, the top two voices become silent. This creates a variety of aural experiences that convey the theme of lamentation.

Monteverdi’s madrigal has a more polyphonic texture than Lasso’s. Consequently, Ah, Dolente partita has a richer sound ambience, but Matona, mia cara has a stronger rhythmic mark. 

As a final contrast, I would like to mention the melodic shape. In Lasso’s madrigal, there are some upward and downward lines, with a lot of repetition of the melody, so it could be sung in a group with a dance-like feeling. Monteverdi’s melody, however, tends to move downward or remain flat, which is most evident towards the end, as if the music is taking small steps toward death.

References

Britannica, The Editors of Encyclopaedia. “Orlando di Lasso”. Encyclopedia Britannica, 10 Jun. 2022, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Orlando-di-Lasso. Accessed 16 September 2022.

MORTENSEN, B., 2009. Recording Reviews – [Claudio Monteverdi: Madrigals]: “Flaming Heart”; “Fire and Ashes”. Choral Journal, 50(5), pp. 60-61. Accessed 16 September 2022.
