item.title: Listening to Oscar Peterson – Hymn To Freedom
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: I came across Oscar Peterson through a Mic.com article called “Did Jazz Forget About Oscar Petterson?”. The author points…
item.content:encoded:
I came across Oscar Peterson through a Mic.com article called “Did Jazz Forget About Oscar Petterson?”. The author points out that when you think about jazz names, Petterson’s is not the first that comes to your mind (Johnson, 2022).

Until today, I was unaware of Oscar Peterson’s name or work. Therefore, I decided to listen to “Hymn To Freedom”, a song featured in the article.

Oscar Peterson was born in Montreal, Canada on August 15, 1925 and grew up in a family where music was required of all five children. At the age of seven, he was able to play trumpet and piano. In his teens, he was already a prodigy when he became the star attraction of Canada’s renowned big band, the Johnny Holmes Orchestra (Peterson, 2003), and he was just 20 years old when he made his first trio recordings for RCA.

As a result of his musical genius, he was able to play with and alongside many jazz legends of the era, including Ella Fitzgerald, Roy Eldridge, Louis Armstrong, Charlie Parker, and Billie Holiday (Johnson, 2022).

From 1959-1965, he formed and played with the Oscar Peterson trio with Ray Brown on bass and Ed Thigpen on drums, becoming one of jazz history’s most celebrated groups. Jazz historian Alyn Shipton explains one of their strengths as “Peterson’s skill at promoting group interaction marked the beginning of a seismic shift in piano trios.” (Hansen, 2014).

During the 1960s, there was racial segregation throughout the United States and Canada, and Peterson suffered a lot of racism when he toured with the Oscar Peterson trio. However, the experience of touring all over the world and especially his experiences in the south of the United States and observing the approach Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. took to peaceful protest, led him to write his most influential work, the “Hymn to Freedom” (Small, 2021).

People all over the world quickly embraced “Hymn To Freedom” as the anthem of the Civil Rights Movement when it was written in 1962. A timeless and relevant piece, this song has been played at many major events around the globe.

This song’s main melody captured my attention from the first listen. The song reminded me of a gospel song infused with blues and jazz. 

In terms of structure, Peterson plays the melody four times before going into his solo, then returning to the original melody one last time. I believe this is an effective way of structuring a hymn, since the first four times he repeats the melody with almost no variation. As a result, the listener is able to engage with the melodic intention of the song. The piano solo builds upon the previous chord progression, but it is melodically much more unique than those first four repetitions, creating some interest. He concludes the solo with an apotheosis, but then the original melody is played softer, calmer, bringing peace to the listener’s heart.

My favorite part of this melody is the contrary motion technique, in which both voices go in opposite directions. While I’m still trying to figure out why I find it so pleasing to hear, I think it’s because it constantly creates a broader range of sounds. This makes it bigger and more interesting as a way of moving to the next part.

References

Johnson, M., 2022. DID JAZZ FORGET ABOUT OSCAR PETERSON?. [online] Mic.Com. Available at: https://www.mic.com/culture/oscar-peterson-black-white [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Hansen, F.A., 2014, The arrangement qualities and musical style of the Oscar Peterson Trio: 1959–1965, Five Towns College [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Peterson, O., 2003, “A Jazz Odyssey: The Life of Oscar Peterson”, Jazz Education Journal, vol. 35, no. 4, pp. C2-C4, C7 [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Small, C., 2021. The Black + White Truth about Oscar Peterson and racism in Canada. POV Magazine. Available at: https://povmagazine.com/the-black-white-truth-about-oscar-peterson-and-racism-in-canada/ [Accessed September 15, 2022].

item.content:encoded:
Since I was unfamiliar with Gesualdo’s work and its significance in music history, I did some research on this post.

Exercise 1.0

  • Listen to the madrigal Beltà poi che t’assenti by Gesualdo.
  • With reference to a score, identify the chords in the first four bars. The answer is given at the end of the chapter.
  • Does this chord progression call to mind any music you know from later eras?
  • How would you describe the music in bb. 9-20 and the texture at bb. 40-42?
  • What does the word ‘dolore’ mean at b. 55?
  • In your own words, describe the kind of harmony, melody and texture that Gesualdo has employed to carry its meaning.
With reference to a score, identify the chords in the first four bars. The answer is given at the end of the chapter.

The chords are G minor, E major, D major, G major, D major, and F# Major.

Does this chord progression call to mind any music you know from later eras?

Although it didn’t sound like anything I’d heard before, I researched why this progression sounded so good together. One of the hints I found was that Gesualdo used mediant chords and doubly chromatic mediant chords, which indeed is true in this chord progression. E major is a doubly chromatic mediant from G minor.

Wagner used the mediant chords in the Magic Sleep Leitmotive from the Ring Cycle.

How would you describe the music in bb. 9-20 and the texture at bb. 40-42?

In bars 9-20, I would describe it as a chromatic imitative counterpoint.

The texture at bb. 40-42 is homophonic.

What does the word ‘dolore’ mean at b. 55?

It means pain, sorrow, and grief.

In your own words, describe the kind of harmony, melody and texture that Gesualdo has employed to carry its meaning.

By itself, the word “dolore” implies sorrow, but in the context of the text, it can also mean relief.

“but a soul without a heart can feel no sorrow.”

If the character dies or at least has his heart figuratively taken away, he becomes numb and cannot feel pain. A relief from the grief associated with the lover’s departure.

This is why the texture starts out polyphonic and with dissonances and then turns homophonic and consonant. Additionally, the melody creates a U shape. Starting moving downwards, taking the meaning of the word “dolore” to inconsolable grief, shifting to a rising melody towards the final G major chord. I interpret this last rising as Gesualdo’s acceptance of pain as an immutable truth or perhaps a morbid pleasure from the composer suffering from insanity at the end of his life.

item.title: Listening to Gesualdo
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: I must admit that I didn’t know who Gesualdo was until today, so I had to make some…
item.content:encoded:
I must admit that I didn’t know who Gesualdo was until today, so I had to make some research about the composer.

A Prince who composed secular madrigals, sacred vocal music, and instrumental music, Carlo Gesualdo da Venosa (c 1566 – 1613) published six books of madrigals and three books of sacred pieces during his lifetime. He was also notorious for brutally murdering his wife and lover in bed. In addition to this cold-hearted murder, many depraved tales have been told about Gesualdo’s mental health. Through these stories (whether true or not, it’s up for debate), we can trace a psychological portrait behind the composer whose work represents the culmination of Renaissance music at the end of the 16th century.

His harmonic language is still considered daring and extravagant today because it incorporates elements of the late Italian madrigals, characterized by sound experimentalism. He used complex chromaticism in a way that was extraordinary for his time. This would not be heard again, or even hinted at until Wagner, Schoenberg and Stravinsky took it to new heights.

This idiosyncratic use of chromaticism was not only an attempt to break the rules, representing his era in which Mannerism was emerging as deliberately disruptive but also had a rather specific objective: word painting.

As an example, when the subject of Amor, pace non chero of his 1st Book of Madrigals calls for his lover, he uses consonance and long notes (Garbuio & Fiorini, 2015).

But in Mille volte il moro of his 6th Book of Madrigals, the Morte (death) is described with uncontrolled polyphony and highly dissonant intervals (Garbuio & Fiorini, 2015).

It’s interesting to see how the technical complexity and themes changed from one book to another during his short life. The polyphonic tradition of the Renaissance dominates the first two books, while harmonic experimentalism dominates the third and fourth books. The last two, however, are characterized by more chromatic and dissonant writing, typically associated with mature composers. Considering the themes, his first two books are more simplistic, whereas his last two books are more dramatic in depicting themes of torture, pain, sadness, and death.

It surprised me to find that although we see Gesualdo as an avant-garde musical genius of his time, some people consider him conservative.

“As conservative as it was possible to be in this time. Monteverdi was the radical, the new. There is a very curious letter from the poet Guarini, in which he says he prefers Gesualdo to the modern style because he is ‘so far from the hardness of Monteverdi.’ For Guarini, Gesualdo is so nice, so easy! Exactly the opposite of what we now think.”

(Ross, 2011)

Even though other contemporary composers experimented with new sonorities and pushed further the boundaries of what music could be, I believe Gesualdo was one of the leading composers of the late Renaissance. While developing polyphony, a better sense of structure and rhythmic order, he explored contrasting emotions (like in Dolcissima mia vita) and influenced composers hundreds of years after his death.

References

Ross, A., 2011. Gesualdo. Alex Ross: The Rest Is Noise. Available at: https://www.therestisnoise.com/2011/12/gesualdo.html [Accessed September 14, 2022].

Burton-Hill, C., 2014. Gesualdo: Glorious music and grisly murder. BBC Culture. Available at: https://www.bbc.com/culture/article/20130905-a-16th-century-musical-badass [Accessed September 14, 2022].

It hadn’t occurred to me that the two first pages were denser than the rest, so I spread them out.

item.title: Listening to Claude Bolling and Jean-Pierre Rampal – Baroque and Blue
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: It is possible to use classical instruments like the flute in other genders while maintaining their identity. Composers…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • It is possible to use classical instruments like the flute in other genders while maintaining their identity.
  • Composers can use both traditional and experimental composition to create new and yet familiar sounds.
  • There are still a number of huge commercial successes I’m not aware of and I should look into finding more.

After researching Bach’s fugues, I came across Suite for Flute and Jazz Piano by Claude Bolling and Jean-Pierre Rampal. The music on this album is an exciting combination of a classical flute and a jazz piano trio.

This album has a really simple story behind it. A French virtuoso jazz pianist, Bolling was Duke Ellington’s “spiritual son”. During his career, he was a pianist, composer and bandleader who wrote more than 100 film scores in a variety of styles (John, 2020). The ease with which he adapted to other musical environments led him to Jean-Pierre Rampal.

Rampal is known as one of the greatest flautists ever, having made the flute a concert instrument and showing how it can adapt to different forms of music (Britannica, 2021).

As Rampal listened to Bolling’s Sonata for Two Pianists, he asked him to come up with an album that would allow a musical dialogue between a classical flute and a jazz piano (Sklar, 2010). They then composed and recorded the album as a suite of seven movements in 1975, which was a huge commercial success and spent more than a decade on the Billboard classical albums chart.

One of the seven movements, Baroque and Blue, is the album’s first piece. Originally composed for flute, piano, double bass, and drums, this piece is exceptionally memorable after you listen to it for the first time. Rampal and Bolling combined two worlds the listener is used to in a way that seemed new and yet familiar at the same time.

Even though this isn’t my favourite track on the album, I feel that it is a good way for the listener to be ready to hear what is to come in the following tracks.

First, we hear the flute’s motif followed by an imitation of the piano, reminiscent of Bach’s fugues. Following some more imitation between the piano and the flute, a familiar jazz sound is introduced by the jazz trio. Here’s how the composers introduce the listener to the combination of jazz and classical music.

We hear a lighthearted, lively, and crisp dialogue between a traditional flute sound, which I feel does not quite capture the swing of jazz, and a jazz trio delivering cool riffs and a feeling of nightclub swing.

In the end, I have the impression that I’m listening to extremely virtuoso musicians who are trying something out of their comfort zone that, while not a masterpiece, is very enjoyable to listen to.

References

Claude Bolling: a living legend turns 80: Duke Ellington’s “spiritual son” talks about his pleasure with the success of his collaboration with Jean-Pierre Rampal, his musical influences, and his love of trains, Flutist Quarterly, available: <https://link.gale.com/apps/doc/A243799691/AONE?u=ucca&sid=summon&xid=db00a6d1> [Accessed 24 December 2021].

item.content:encoded:
In part 5 of this unit, I explored the role harmony plays in music. To put my research into practice, I composed some exercises to practise chord progressions. The result was that I gained a deeper understanding of how chord harmony supports a melody.

In part 4, I introduced chords through tuned percussion instruments; in part 5, I took it a step further with the piano. As a result, I was able to create a more complex and interesting sound, but it also posed some new challenges. For example, how to create chords that go beyond the simple triad or how to utilize arpeggios instead of chords to keep the sound moving.

In order to provide a fresh perspective to my listening log, my tutor suggested that I listen to contemporary classical music artists. My experience with this was quite interesting as I once again ventured outside of my comfort zone and discovered some inspiring artists.

About Assignment 5

So far, this was my favourite assignment. My ability to explore various sonorities and the introduction of the piano opened up many possibilities for me.

Even though I did not go far outside my comfort zone as I did in assignment four, I tried to create some familiar-sounding passages while adding some novel and unusual parts that I am not entirely sure are good.

The cyclic chord progression was useful in constructing the melody, and I used it five times with two different chord progressions.

In the previous parts of this unit, we’ve learned that if we modify or augment the same sounds, we can be more economical with the material. In this assignment, I tried to do this, and I was very pleased with the results.

Having reviewed all the assignments I completed, I can clearly see how my sense of rhythm and melody developed along with my confidence.

item.title: Assignment 5: Harmony in the round
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In assignment 5, I had to compose a piece that used Cyclic chord progressions at least four times…
item.content:encoded:
In assignment 5, I had to compose a piece that used Cyclic chord progressions at least four times within a three-minute span. Although I could compose with any instruments of my choice, I was asked to avoid using a Perfect Cadence until the very end of the piece.

You can find the final score here and listen to it below:

The Idea / Theme

I decided to use what I learned from my research on tango in this assignment and create a tango-inspired piece. The reason I would not call it a Tango is that I feel I need to dig deeper to find out what makes a memorable Tango piece, and mainly because I don’t want to offend tango lovers.

Additionally, I had fun playing with the element of surprise in my last assignment. Even though the use of cyclic chord progressions may mean repetition, I aim to include some unexpected elements in this piece to prevent it from becoming monotonous.

Regarding the theme, I believe that tango is much about passion and desire, so this piece is about love in all its forms. For instance, it can include passionate love, admiration for a friend, or care for a family member. All of these types of love have one thing in common: they are never linear. They have ups and downs, calm moments, passionate moments, turbulent moments. If it is true love, everything will finally make sense and end in a perfect cadence.

As with all relationships, both parties have unique personalities. Due to this, I chose two woodwind instruments (Flute and Oboe) with a narrator (Piano) to lead the listener through the piece. 

Structure

The structure is based on the concept that each voice has a chance to “speak” and then interact with the other voice. As a result, the structure becomes A-B-C-B’-A’, where A is dominated by the personality of the first voice, B is dominated by the personality of the second voice, and C is where they interact.

I selected the key of B minor for no particular reason other than it sounded good with a theme I was playing on the piano. Later in the C section, I wanted to modulate to the dominant key, in this case, F# minor.

The Motifs

From the beginning, I knew I wanted two motifs, one for the flute and one for the oboe. Each motif must be different and appear throughout the piece.

The oboe motif is more melodic and romantic, which I think is perfect for an oboe in the middle range.

The oboe and piano play a fraction of this motif in bars 29-30.

All instruments repeat this fraction in bars 62-66.

Unlike the first voice, the flute’s motif is mostly semiquavers and is more rhythmic.

All instruments repeat this motif in bars 51-53.

This motif is augmented by the piano in bars 55-58.

The piece also includes a note-descending motif that does not belong to any particular instrument and is played throughout in order to tie all sections together. It first appears in bars 5 and 6 on the oboe.

The flute plays a version of it in bars 22-23 and 28-29.

The flute plays this motif in bars 33-34 (inside its own motif), but it has been slighlty transformed.

In bars 58-59, the piano and flute repeat this motif.

The Rhytms

Tango is much about rhythm, so I tried to convey it in this piece. As I found out in my research on tango, there are two distinct accompaniment rhythms: marcato and síncopa. Most of this piece uses síncopa, as for example at the beginning.

In Bars 17-20, as well as in Section C, the marcato is present.

The Instruments

I began to think about the piece at this point. We were told that we could use any instrument of our choice, but the hint was that we could use the piano as well. Because I had never composed for the piano before, I decided to research what woodwind instruments were used with the piano. I chose the piano – flute – oboe combination because I enjoyed listening to how the three instruments sound completely different in Madeleine Dring’s Trio for Flute, Oboe and Piano.

Upon hearing Lalliet’s Terzetto, I immediately thought of composing for the bassoon since it sounded very good with the oboe and piano. Then I realized several of my compositions have bassoons in them, so I decided to leave it out of this assignment.

This arrangement of Schumann’s 6 Studien in kanonischer Form, Op. 56: IV for oboe and piano was really interesting to listen to. I liked how the oboe suits the piano so well.

This performance of Jean-Michael Damase’s Trio caught my interest since I was curious to hear how the horn would sound in a three-piece ensemble. Although I have always considered the horn to be a beautiful instrument, here it sometimes sounded well, but in other instances it was too imposing.

The Composition

Section A Bars 1-20

The first part of this section is dominated by the piano and the oboe, with the latter providing a more melodic voice. There’s something a bit romantic and a little cliché about this melody, giving me a gentle humming of Carlos Gardel’s voice. In order to convey that this is an inspired piece of tango music, I made this intentionally.

In this section, the chord progression is i – ii° – iv – III – VII⁶. I developed this progression because I wanted to begin with only minor chords and move to major chords in the last part.

This chord progression is broken up in a transition to the B section using a classic tango rhythm and letting the piano alone so the flute can enter more dramatically. 

Section B Bars 21-38

Bars 21-30 (the first ten bars) continue the previous transition with the introduction of the flute in a high E semibreve. A new chord progression is hinted at in bars 26-30, especially when the C major chord is introduced.

The flute’s motif is introduced with a new chord progression i – iv – ♮II – vi – V – VI from bar 31 to bar 34, which is repeated twice until the end of section B.

I wanted both rhythm and harmony to contrast in this section. Despite the fact that the piano uses essentially the same rhythm as section A, the flute uses mostly semiquavers. Harmonically, I introduce some non-diatonic chords that contrast feelings and surprise the listener.

Section C Bars 39-50

In bars 39-42, I chose to take the contrast a step further with a brief modulation to the key of F# minor. Additionally, the rhythm changes to a marcato rhythm that is played throughout section C.

This section is more contrapuntal, where instruments play their own melodies and none of the previous motifs are heard, creating an impression that this is a completely new section.

Section B’ Bars 51-61

The piece returns to its familiarity in section B’ with the previous chord progression i – iv – ♮II – vi – V – VI and interplay between instruments that echo a motif from section B. The climax is reached when both woodwind instruments play a high minim. That is the highest note played by the oboe so far.

A piano solo follows, and the piece moves back to a softer sound.

Section A’ Bars 62-68

The final section begins by mimicking the beginning of the B’ section, in which the instruments play the motif of the A section in turn.

The voices calm down until there is a perfect cadence.

item.title: Listening to Kaija Saariaho – Vista
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Spectral music is about experimenting with sound through overtones and creating aural atmospheres through layering. Saariaho showed that…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • Spectral music is about experimenting with sound through overtones and creating aural atmospheres through layering.
  • Saariaho showed that rules should be viewed as guidelines rather than restrictions.
  •  A song does not need to depict a moving image. Music can depict a still moment, just like a painting.

To gain a better understanding of what contemporary classical musicians are preoccupied with, my tutor challenged me to listen to more contemporary classical music. I chose Kaija Saariaho after reading that BBC Music Magazine named her the greatest living composer in 2019 (Fiilin, 2019) and the New York Times named her Composer of the Year 2021 (Barone, 2021).

Kaija Saariaho’s sound was completely new to me because I had never heard it before.

Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho, born in 1952, studied composition at Sibelius Academy and then moved to Germany to study at the Hochschule für Musik Freiburg. During this time she felt frustrated by all the forbidden things of post-serialist tradition. “You were not allowed to have a pulse, or tonally oriented harmonies, or melodies,” she said. “I don’t want to write music through negations. Everything is permissible as long as it’s done in good taste” (Posner, 2018).

In 1980, she first encountered spectral music in France, where she eventually settled. Throughout her career, her work has been influenced by themes that have circulated in French music for decades: melody and harmony derived from overtones, and the fusion of instrumental and electronic elements. IRCAM, which Pierre Boulez founded in 1977, has been an important part of her career (Ross, 2006).

Like Saariaho in 1980, I was unfamiliar with spectralism. The method of using overtones to examine sonorities was a different approach to music, although it isn’t completely novel in terms of music theory. Overtone series is the building block of Western music – the octave, the fourth, the fifth, and the major third. The beauty of spectral music lies in the way the different instruments explore and utilize the overtones without becoming dull and boring. 

I chose Vista because it is a composition from 2021, and I was curious to know what a great composer is working on at the moment. I found this recording of the Helsinki City Orchestra conducted by Susanna Mälkki.

In my mind, music has always been like motion, like a slice of life imagined by the composer, or a scene from a film transcribed into music. However, I found that Saariaho’s music can be compared to a picture. In this still moment, all the acoustic nuances combine to create what I believe could be a musical photograph.  

Vista, which has two parts – Horizons and Targets, left me with the impression that this was a scene that the composer had imagined. She describes this scene to the listener and how it made her feel.

The scene in Horizons is a very open one, perhaps a field or the sea. She couldn’t see the end of it, perhaps it was a very flat landscape. The scenery is serene, allowing you to enjoy nature’s beauty. I would love to see some paintings inspired by Horizons.

Although it uses the same instruments from the previous piece, Targets has a completely different soundscape. It is rough, dry, and turbulent. This looks like a mountainous landscape, with sharp geometric shapes everywhere you look. It’s not prettier or uglier than Horizons’ landscape, but neither is it peaceful. Maybe it’s near a city and you can feel the stress.

I enjoyed listening to Vista because it opened up a new musical world to me. Also outstanding about this work is the score, which I found particularly interesting due to the detailed notation for the players.

References

item.title: Project 14 – Improvisation on a dominant
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In this project, we were asked to improvise on a dominant, as long as it stayed interesting, until…
item.content:encoded:
In this project, we were asked to improvise on a dominant, as long as it stayed interesting, until ending in a perfect cadence.

I aimed to make a longer composition, but I struggled to keep it interesting, so I chose to shorten it in order to not bore the listener.

This exercise is in the key of A major, making the dominant chord the E major. The left hand is always playing the E major chord, which turns into E major 7 on bar 5, and returns to E major on bar 7. Then, on bar 9, it plays an arpeggio of the E major and its inversions, until it reaches the final cadence, from E to A.

The right hand is more fluid and plays a melody that is much more interesting than the left hand repetition. I believe that this contrast makes interesting anticipation for the release of the tension on bar 15.

You can download the Sibelius file here.

item.title: Project 13: Elaborate cadences
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: The aim of this project was to create four different V-I Cadences, each in a different key. Two…
item.content:encoded:
The aim of this project was to create four different V-I Cadences, each in a different key. Two of them were to be major and the other two minor.

 For this exercise, we are asked to make four contrasting attempts at ‘dressing up’ a perfect cadence, each in a different key, of which two should be major, and two minor. I was looking forward to attempting this exercise, as the theory is straightforward but there is lots of room for creativity.

Exercise 1

The first example is in the key of C major and is completely diatonic. I wanted to give some movement to this cadence, so the right hand is in a descending and ascending journey from G (V) to C(I), and there’s some syncopation in the left hand also. In the third bar, the V moves to a V7 just before ending in I.

Exercise 2

In this second exercise, I picked the A major key. I wanted to build tension in this exercise just before being released by the perfect cadence. This is achieved by going up in the right hand, while the left hand plays variations of the V and V7. After getting to a high D, the melody goes down until the perfect cadence V-I.

Exercise 3

This exercise is in the key of Eb minor. After composing this exercise, it sounded like Honegger’s piece I listened at the beginning of this unit. Here, I built up the cadence with right-hand arpeggios and with the left hand going through the notes of the Bb minor chord until the perfect cadence is achieved.

Exercise 4

This exercise is in the key of A minor, and has a very fast melody on top of a diatonic bassline. I think this exercise was inspired by my research on ragtime but with a really simple chord progression of I-V-I.

item.title: Listening to Astor Piazzola – Las Cuatro Estaciones Porteñas
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Trying to sound like famous composers can make you feel as though you are creating something of quality,…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • Trying to sound like famous composers can make you feel as though you are creating something of quality, but sounding like yourself will set you apart from others.
  • The tango rhythms are really simple, but if you play with tempo and melody, you can get a lot of variety. 
  • In this work, the violins show that instruments can be just as expressive as the human voice.

In researching Ragtime, I discovered that this music style resembled Tango in some ways. As it turns out, ragtime and tango share some rhythmic styles, such as bass syncopation (Berlin, 2013).

As a result, I learned more about Tango and one of its greatest composers: Astor Piazzolla. Although I had heard Piazzolla before, I hadn’t listened to his Four Seasons work. Consequently, I decided to listen to it.

Piazzolla was born in Mar del Plata, Argentina, on March 11, 1921. When he was eight years old, his family moved to New York, USA, from where he got his first bandoneon before moving back to Argentina and then again to the USA. As a result of all of this back and forth between Argentina and the US, he was influenced by Tango and Jazz in all of his work (Bach, 1991).

As a 12-year-old, he was already a prolific bandoneon player, until he met Carlos Gardel, one of his idols. He eventually became Gardel’s translator and bandoneon player as well.

In 1946, Piazzolla moved back to Argentina and formed his own orchestra. He then travelled to France for a Paris Conservatory scholarship. However, his secret goal on this trip to France was to meet Nadia Boulanger, one of the greatest music teachers to ever live (Burton-Hill, 2017). In response to a symphony he composed, she gave him some great advice: “Something is missing You sound like Ravel, Bartok, Stravinsky, Hindemith but you don’t sound like Piazzolla. Where is Astor Piazzolla in all this? What do you do!” (Bach, 1991).

Nadia Boulanger encouraged Piazzolla to pursue what would become known as the New Tango, a unique fusion of tango, jazz, and classical music. His favourite instruments for tango nuevo were the bandoneon, violin, bass, piano, and electric guitar.

I can hear all of these influences in his Buenos Aires Four Seasons, or in the original title Las Cuatro Estaciones Porteñas.

As opposed to Vivaldi’s Four Seasons, Piazzolla treated the four pieces separately rather than as a single suite. The summer was written in 1965, the winter in 1969, and the spring and autumn in 1970. However, he sometimes performed them together in concerts. In this composition, the four seasons are presented with the focus on Buenos Aires, meaning that each season is seen and heard through the eyes and ears of a city bursting with life and activity.

In 1998, Leonid Desyatnikov composed a new arrangement linked to Vivaldi’s work for solo violin and string orchestra. Instead of listening to this arrangement, I will listen to the original bandoneon arrangement played by Piazzolla.

It was generally very enjoyable, particularly the contrast between energetic and almost chaotic forces and subtle and gentle melodies. All of the “seasons” follow some kind of fast-slow-fast pattern, which makes them feel very different from what traditional tango used to be.

In traditional tango, the time signature is 4/4 and there are two simple rhythms: marcato, where there are four marks on the beat; and síncopa, where there is an off-beat pattern that includes a number of variations like the most famous Habanera. In Piazzolla’s Las Cuatro Estaciones Porteñas, I can hear both rhythms but particularly Autumn has a very interesting habanera rhythm.

Spring

The city is waking up from a rainy winter and moving towards sunny days in the spring. In a way, spring is the beginning of life. This is especially evident in this piece where the violin makes a sound that sounds almost like a shout of joy, at mark 01:00. People start moving out of their houses and partying on the streets.

Around 02:30, the calmer part begins and I believe this is a time for romance. As the Spring lovers appear and the seduction begins, Piazzolla demonstrates that Tango is not just about the party and energetic rhythms, it can also be about beautiful and tranquil melodies.

We return to the energetic motif at 03:20 because spring is about letting go of all the tension accumulated during the winter and enjoying the wonderful weather outside.

Summer

Summer in Buenos Aires is extremely hot, making it difficult to spend time outside during the day. I believe that’s why this piece is not as energetic as Spring. There is some repetition within the melody itself because that is what the heat does to you. Everything becomes more lethargic. The joy returns in the late afternoon and evening. During mark 09:30, we hear the same shouts of joy as in the Spring piece, as well as a hint of celebration and romance.

Piazzolla’s violin solo brings back the lethargy of the very hot and humid summer of Buenos Aires because perhaps in his mind the daytime has returned.

The joy returns at the end with a bit of joy and síncopa to help bring about a festive mood with the end of summer and colder days to come.

Autumn

While spring is the season for birth, Autumn brings a sense of death and tranquillity. Particularly at mark 17:00, the previous violin shouts have less power and sound almost sad. It brings melancholy to our ears with the nostalgia of spring and summer and the anticipation of a cold winter that comes slowly to us. I feel that by the end of this piece. There are huge, heavy steps of coming winter.

Winter

During the winter, the city moves indoors. Because everything is a little calmer and colder, the tango sounds a little warmer as if it could warm the heart of the dancers. In this piece, I believe Piazzolla envisioned couples dancing close to each other to this tango in order to warm each other and maybe have a little romance in the winter.

The electric guitar sound is quite dominant in this piece, which I believe is meant to emphasize the warm sound needed for the cold winter, just like a musical fireplace.

In the second half, the music starts to gain energy, probably trying to make the anticipation of the Spring to come.

Around mark 26:00, the sound shifts into classical, perhaps a nod to Vivaldi’s work.

References

Berlin, E., 2013. Ragtime. [online] Grove Music Online. Available at: <https://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/grovemusic/view/10.1093/gmo/9781561592630.001.0001/omo-9781561592630-e-1002252241> [Accessed 4 December 2021].

Bach, Caleb, 1991. Astor Piazzolla: a new-age score for the tango. The Free Library. Available at: <https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Astor Piazzolla: a new-age score for the tango.-a011810151> [Accessed 4 December 2021].

Burton-Hill, C., 2017. The greatest music teacher who ever lived. [online] Bbc.com. Available at: <https://www.bbc.com/culture/article/20170308-the-greatest-music-teacher-who-ever-lived> [Accessed 4 December 2021].

item.title: Listening to Richard Wagner – Das Rheingold, Prelude
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: One key can leave a lot of room for creativity. Repetition can be made more interesting by using…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • One key can leave a lot of room for creativity.
  • Repetition can be made more interesting by using dynamics.
  • Leitmotifs are motifs that represent characters, objects, places, and specific emotions.

This is a prelude from the first opera of Wagner’s mythic four-opera cycle, The Ring, composed in 1874. It begins on the Rhine, where the Rhinemaidens protect the precious Rheingold (Kay, n.d.). This is the scene that this Prelude establishes.

Upon hearing it, my first reaction was that it was one of the most remarkable openings I have ever heard. Not because of its complexity or memorable themes, quite the opposite. This concept is actually very simple: an entire prelude made out of just one key, E flat major, that doesn’t go anywhere harmonically. Or maybe it moves to a perfect cadence after 136 bars, and E flat is the V of the A flat that starts the next scene.

In the Prelude to Das Rheingold, the double bass in E flat starts slowly and barely audibly rumbling. Later, the bassoon in B flat is added, followed by the rest of the instruments in a series of layers of repetitive sounds. As the piece progresses, simple notes played in a drone-like manner are accompanied by the increased and overlaid sounds of multiple instruments played without a clearly defined rhythm and downbeat.

The composer’s intention was to create a mood of birth, I believe. As in nature, the instruments multiply, much like the cells of a growing organism. Possibly here is the birth of the river Rhine, or even the whole universe as it sets up the Opera. When one listens to this piece with their eyes closed and thinks about the birth of anything, one can imagine it starting from something small and growing into something beautiful.

Researching this Prelude, I found that it is used at the beginning of the movie The New World when the English ship arrives in 1607 to establish Jamestown, an English colony in Virginia. This confirms my belief in the atmosphere created by this Prelude.

In researching this piece, I also came across the concept of Leitmotifs. With leitmotifs (leading motifs) Wagner represented characters, objects, places, and specific emotions. In this piece, there are three leitmotifs: nature or genesis, the river or Rhein and the waves (Trythall, n.d.).

My favourite thing about these leitmotifs is that they resemble waves whose intensity increases. In addition to being waves of sound, they can also be perceived as waves of a waking river – the Rhein. With these leitmotifs, Wagner, I believe, wanted the audience to feel that they were going down in a river and there was nothing they could do but go with the flow.

Having listened and investigated this piece, I now have a better understanding of the concept of leitmotifs, which was not created by Wagner, but taken up by him and developed to the highest level of musical expression in the four operas that make up Der Ring des Nibelungen (BBC Radio 3 – Opera on 3 – Wagner’s The Ring – Leitmotives, n.d.). From my perspective, this concept had a tremendous impact on music and influenced generations to come. Now, leitmotifs are a common occurrence in movie soundtracks. Think of Darth Vader’s theme or Jaw’s two-note suspense. Even advertising has benefited from the development of this concept since jingles have become leitmotifs for brands.

References

Kay, G., n.d. BBC Radio 3 – Opera on 3 – Wagner’s The Ring – plot essentials. [online] BBC. Available at: https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/3KgB2xl02TSCYYf0QkmZ8B0/wagners-the-ring-plot-essentials [Accessed 2 December 2021].

Trythall, R., n.d. UCCD2A Das Rheingold Leitmotifs. [online] Richardtrythall.com. Available at: <http://richardtrythall.com/UCCD2A.html> [Accessed 2 December 2021].

BBC. n.d. BBC Radio 3 – Opera on 3 – Wagner’s The Ring – Leitmotives. [online] Available at: <https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/5W3xDK5Y93WPlfbZj0s3LvS/wagners-the-ring-leitmotives> [Accessed 2 December 2021].

item.title: Listening to Beethoven – Piano Concerto No.5 in Eb, Op.73 I. Allegro
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Beethoven demonstrates how a theme can be repeated through a work and never become monotonous. Beethoven may hold…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • Beethoven demonstrates how a theme can be repeated through a work and never become monotonous.
  • Beethoven may hold a large part of the credit for today’s concept of chorus in pop music.
  • Cadenzas can be improvised by the player or written by the composer.

Because of my research on Cadenza, I ended up listening to Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 5, especially the first movement Allegro. In my opinion, this concerto is a perfect example of Beethoven’s ability to infuse rhythm, depth a power into music.

This first movement starts with a rather unusual presentation of the orchestra and the solo instrument, in this case, the piano. The orchestra plays open chords while the piano plays flourishes of arpeggios, trills, and scales.

Then comes the theme, which in my opinion is very powerful and almost a fanfare.

The development shows all the creative genius of Beethoven, who created a stunning piece that contains repeating themes and different elaborations of them by both the orchestra and the piano.

One thing I found interesting is the duality of the piano – orchestra because from my listening I think that the piano is more experimental and spontaneous, while the orchestra tends to stay more predictable and harmonious. I believe this was a deliberate thought of Beethoven to create some tension and interest in this 20-minute movement.

The cadenza of Piano Concerto No. 5 a.k.a. Emperor Concerto is a very short part of this piece and it was written by Beethoven, probably because he was unable to perform it and wanted to control all the narrative of this concerto. Following this Emperor Concerto, writing the cadenzas became a common feature among contemporary composers (Lindeman, 1995).

References

Lindeman, S., 1995. Formal novelty and tradition in the early romantic piano concerto. Rutgers The State University of New Jersey – New Brunswick, p.32.

item.title: Researching Cadenza
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: One of the things I’m finding most interesting in this course is that I’m putting names and concepts…
item.content:encoded:
One of the things I’m finding most interesting in this course is that I’m putting names and concepts in things I loved about music. It happened with counterpoint and it happened now with cadenza.

Cadenza is, according to The Oxford Dictionary of Music, “a flourish (properly, improvised) inserted into the final cadence of any section of a vocal aria or a solo instr movement” (Kennedy, Kennedy and Rutherford-Johnson, 2012). This music usually culminates in an extended trill, after which the orchestra re-enters, bringing the movement to a speedy conclusion, more often than not without any further participation from the soloist.

The practice of cadenzas originated in vocal music where singers improvised at certain cadences within an aria. The general rule for vocal music was that the cadenza would last no longer than a breath. Composers preferred that performers keep their cadenzas short to prevent interference with the structure of the aria. Since Mozart and Beethoven were writing for their own performances, they felt no inclination to keep things and took this opportunity to show their flashy keyboard skills (Fuller, n.d.).

In other words, it can be described as a parenthesis in music, where the author (in the case of a written cadenza) or the player (in the case of an improvised cadenza) take the liberty of getting out of the structure of the music and create a new focal point of the piece (Bribitzer-Stull, Matthew, 2006).

After hearing some cadenzas (shown below) I believe that the cadenza has two main purposes: one in itself and the other within the piece. The first is to showcase the singer/player skills; the second is to anticipate a climactic ending.

Going back to the beginning of this post, now I know what Freddie Mercury (one of my favourite composers) was doing when, for example, he used a little cadenza at the end of Barcelona (at minute 3:50) or a slightly bigger one at the end of the live performance of Somebody To Love (at minute 5:00). In both examples, he was showcasing the vocal skills of the singer (Montserrat Caballé’s skill in the first example, which can be thought of a melisma) and leading the music into an apotheotic ending.

Maybe there are other examples of cadenzas in more popular music, but I can’t find them. Below are the classical examples I listened to.

Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart – Piano Concerto No. 20 in D minor, K. 466. Mvt. 1: Allegro

This is one of the most cited cadenzas I found through all articles I read. Probably because it joins the work of two geniouses: Mozart’s concerto and Beethoven’s cadenza. Mozart’s Piano Concerto was given its premiere in Vienna on 1785, with the composer at the piano, but sadly, Mozart’s own cadenza was lost. A few years later in 1809, Beethoven wrote his own.

It’s full of contrasts and unexpected twists and turns and a fantastic final stretched with a trill that lasts several bars before the orchestra comes in. I was expecting a more virtuosic challenge for the pianist, but what I believe Beethoven achieved was a more emotional and impassioned cadenza.

Beethoven – Piano Concerto No. 5 in E flat major op. 73

This cadenza that appears near the end of the first movement, was written by the composer itself and it is a really short but elaborate part of this piece. What I found interesting about this cadenza is that it fits the whole movement very well. It comes from the main theme and makes the passage to another theme.

Before the cadenza, the orchestra plays the powerful dotted quaver – semi quaver – crochet chords while the piano anticipates a bit of the cadenza. Then the short cadenza starts full of rhythm but then gently eases back into the tutti by accompanying the end of the “cadenza” with a horn theme.

Brahms – Violin Concerto in D major, Op. 77

Brahms wrote one violin concerto and it was dedicated to Joseph Joachim. The cadenza appears in the end of Mvt.1 and I believe it is full of passion and melancholy at the same time. It explores the violin capabilites, which fits the purpose of a cadenza: to showcase the player’s and instrument virtuosities.

The dissonant notes and the strikes on the chords convey a bit of rage that I specially aprecciate. With the runs, I felt that it had some rock and metal sound I used to listen to. It brought me memories of the extended electric guitar solos that showcased the guitarist skills.

In the end, the entering of the orchestra is much smoother than the Mozart’s piano concerto, and I believe this creates a great contrast with the cadenza, almost like it is a resolution of the violin’s anger.

References

Kennedy, J., Kennedy, M. and Rutherford-Johnson, T., 2012. cadenza. [online] The Oxford Dictionary of Music. Available at: <https://www-oxfordreference-com.ucreative.idm.oclc.org/view/10.1093/acref/9780199578108.001.0001/acref-9780199578108-e-1488> [Accessed 23 November 2021].

Fuller, M., n.d. BEAUTY of music | the classical cadenza – American Pianists Association. [online] Americanpianists.org. Available at: https://www.americanpianists.org/apa-blog/95-beauty-of-music-the-classical-cadenza [Accessed 24 November 2021].

Bribitzer-Stull, Matthew, 2006. The Cadenza as Parenthesis: An Analytic Approach. Journal of Music Theory 50, no. 2, 211–51. Available at: <http://www.jstor.org/stable/40283099> [Accessed 23 November 2021].

For part 4 of this unit, I had the opportunity to explore how a counterpoint composition can be developed with the main subject as the focal point. Bach’s fugues proved to be of great importance here.

I also explored tuned percussion instruments for the first time. I found them varied and versatile. I will certainly explore composition with the timpani and the glockenspiel.

As a result of listening to Ragtime, I also developed a better understanding of rhythm and syncopation in some compositions.

About Assignment 4

So far, this assignment has been the most challenging. The assignment was difficult for me for a number of reasons, but I suspect it was the challenge of writing something different that I placed on myself.

In general, I am not pleased with the composition. It has some parts that I like, especially the motif and some rhythmic details in section C, but as a whole, it doesn’t appeal to me as much as some of my other compositions.

Despite being aware that a university is a place where people take chances, I will attempt to create something I’m more familiar with in the next assignment to increase my self-confidence.

item.title: Assignment 4
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In assignment 4, I had to compose an imitative counterpoint for around 3 minutes using woodwinds and tuned…
item.content:encoded:
In assignment 4, I had to compose an imitative counterpoint for around 3 minutes using woodwinds and tuned percussion.

You can find the final score here and listen to it below:

The Idea / Theme

Having felt that my previous assignments were a bit on the safe side, I decided to incorporate the element of surprise into this assignment. It was important for me to try things I hadn’t done before. I wanted to go to places that made me uncomfortable and use my ingenuity to see if I could surprise myself.

Regarding the theme, along with the idea of surprise, this piece will be about a party, for instance, a wedding, where a dance will be performed by two voices. Then something goes wrong between these two voices, maybe an argument or an altercation that completely changes the mood. Ultimately, both parties reach an agreement and get back to dancing.

The Structure

The idea largely determines the structure. This turns the structure into an A-B-C-A-B. I envision this piece beginning with an intro (A section) that will be in the same key, but rhythmically different from the B section. When we move from the B section to the C section, there will be a change in key, time signature, tempo, and dynamics to create a full contrast. After this section, we return to the intro and then the B section.

The A section will be in a minor key, the B section in a major key, and the C section in a minor key. In this piece, I will start in the key of E minor, then move to its relative major key of G major. In the C section, I will use the key of B minor, which is a fifth from the key of E minor, because I want to create some contrast without sounding too abrupt.

The Motifs

As I was playing around with the piano, I came up with a motif (in red) that started short and developed into a bigger subject.

The Instruments

Having reviewed a recent video from Philharmonia, I decided to choose the vibraphone because of the sustained sound it produces.

I decided to go with the bassoon for the woodwind instrument again because I am finding it to be much more versatile than I had anticipated.

The combination of these instruments seemed unusual to me, and I was not wrong. Youtube and Spotify returned few results, but I found this performance of a piece by Alexandre Ouzounoff that encouraged me to continue experimenting with these two instruments.

The composition

Section A Bars 1-6

As an introduction to the piece, I composed a short section with both instruments presenting themselves in different moods: the bassoon is strong and sustained, and the vibraphone is fast and harmonious.

I was inspired by Stravinsky’s bassoon solo in Rite Of Spring to start the piece on a high sustained note.

This introduction ends abruptly to convey the main idea of a piece with surprise elements.

Section B Bars 7-26

Here, the time signature changes and the bassoon plays the main subject, copied by the vibraphone. With the bassoon playing a countersubject in E in bar 13, the vibraphone is now free to play the main subject in G, which now is a major third.

In bar 20, the bassoon returns to the main theme but starts in C, which is a major 4th of G. The vibraphone continues to fill the room with ascending and descending notes.

Both instruments start ascending melodies in bar 23, which leads to a climax and the end of this section.

Section C Bars 27-40

The section begins with a low dynamic and just the vibraphone playing. Although the key changes to B minor, I wanted to create another level of surprise and ambiguity, so I played an F major chord on the high notes, while the low notes created dissonance.

This section motif is then played by the bassoon, accompanied by a steady rhythm played by the vibraphone. Sometimes the vibraphone completes a triad, such as the A major in bar 28, but sometimes it just plays dissonant tones.

In the absence of harmony between the instruments, the tension rises with minor triads and the tempo increases.

At Bar 36, both instruments play staccato, and the tempo is the fastest in the entire piece. The vibraphone continues with its ascending and descending melody, while the bassoon is more steady in its notes.

At the end, in bar 40, they are both tired of the previous part and rest in minim notes before concluding with a B major triad.

Section A’ Bars 41-43

The section starts with a chord in G major, marking a key change, and proceeds into a version of the intro.

Section B‘ Bars 44-67

In this section, a bassoon augmented subject is played while the vibraphone plays the motif, followed by a counterpoint.

In bar 56, the bassoon plays an inversion of the subject while the vibraphone plays parts of the motif and triads.

In bar 62, the bassoon plays the main motif, which is quickly repeated by the vibraphone in increasing tones until they both end in a G.

item.title: Listening to Bach’s Fugues
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: The Well-Tempered Clavier, Book 1: Fugue No. 8 in D-Sharp Minor, BWV 853 I felt this fugue was…
item.content:encoded:
The Well-Tempered Clavier, Book 1: Fugue No. 8 in D-Sharp Minor, BWV 853

I felt this fugue was really lovely, especially because I enjoyed the theme and Bach used it frequently throughout this composition. In fact, I thought this fugue was quite theme-centric, with the theme inverted, augmented, and rhythmically varied. It’s also worth noting that this fugue goes from a straightforward exposition to a three-voiced narrative.

To be clear, some sources indicate that this fugue is in Eb minor; nevertheless, the prelude is in Eb minor, but the fugue is in D# minor in most scores I discovered. Although I don’t believe it matters, I’ll keep mentioning that this fugue is in D# minor.

This fugue begins with the first voice exposition of the theme, while the second voice (in red) imitate it. Right away, the lowest voice repeats it a second time. Bach repeats this three-bar theme four times in the first 14 bars, which shows how important this theme is to him.

In order to emphasize the theme-centric nature of the fugue, the theme is repeated five times from bar 19 to bar 29, before there is an inversion (in blue). I was interested to see if the inversion is an exact mirror of the theme. I got my answer right away: no. The very first note, D#, goes to an A#, the perfect fifth. However, the inversion goes down a perfect fourth. Following these first notes, everything is mirrored.

Afterwards, the lower voice plays an augmentation of the theme (in green) at double speed. In my opinion, this is where the piece begins to climax and become more complex.

It is difficult for me to follow and analyze without assistance from here. I noticed that the theme is imitated and reversed as well as amplified and augmented throughout the entire piece, making it a complex and engaging ending.

The Well-Tempered Clavier, Book I: Fugue No. 14 in F-sharp minor, BWV 859

I found this fugue to be slow, sorrowful, but at the same time, I found it to sometimes be beautifully harmonious. Contrary to other fugues I have heard, I believe this could be played in a church, with the long notes resonating in the long walls. Alternatively, a choral group could perform it.

The theme (in red) and countertheme (in brown) are presented in the first six bars of this fugue, which is interesting. The theme’s long notes are precisely counterbalanced by the countertheme’s quavers, allowing both to be heard clearly. When the third voice is added in the lower bass, it sounds really lovely to me. This produces a really fascinating and recognizable sound that binds all of the voices together.

I was curious as to how Bach composed the theme and counter-theme to work together so beautifully, so I decided to investigate further. One thing I observed is that both melodies, especially the countertheme, move in a step-by-step manner, only leaping in the finish. This, I believe, allows the intervals to move from fifths to thirds, as seen at the start of bar 5. In addition, the opposing motion in the first two bars, when one of the melodies rises (in red) and the other falls (in blue), generates a lovely contrast and tension, which is released in the last two bars, when both move in the same direction.

When I previously stated that I considered this piece to be quite harmonic at moments, I was making reference to bars 13 and 14. All melodies, I suppose, have the same function here: to set the stage for the return of the theme and countertheme, but this time in a more powerful form. The theme is mostly played by the two upper voices with the thirds. This brings the piece to a close with a mini-climax.

Something new appears later, at the conclusion of bar 20. The motif has been inverted (in blue). This inversion is accompanied by lower voice quavers that sound like the countertheme. I believe this is employed to have a familiar sound with this new inversion theme.

One last thing I’d like to mention is something I don’t recall hearing in previous fugues. When two voices play similar melodies while the other two wait their time to play identical tunes. As with prior examples, most of this is done using the third interval. All of this builds up to the final theme and countertheme section.

item.title: Listening to Stravinsky – Rite Of Spring
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Bassoons are turning into one of my favourite instruments because of their sound and versatility of being able…
item.content:encoded:
Bassoons are turning into one of my favourite instruments because of their sound and versatility of being able to be both a rhythmic and melodic instrument. As I was researching about it, I came across the introduction to Stravinsky’s Rite Of Spring, where the bassoon plays an extremely unusual high note and a beautiful melody. As a result of this unusual sound, I was drawn to listen to the whole piece more closely.

Rite Of Spring was commissioned by Serge Diaghilev, the noted impresario of the Ballets Russes who had also produced The Firebird (1910) and Petrushka (1911) and it was not a huge hit on opening night (Schwarm, n.d.).

In 1913, the Rite Of Spring was received by the audience at the premiere at the Théâtre des Champs-Elysées in Paris with shouts and yells. There was so much noise that the dancers were unable to hear the orchestra. It was a total disaster (Stravinsky’s The Rite of Spring: Keeping Score | PBS, 2022). However, later became known as one of the most influential pieces of music of the 20th century.

This piece was influenced by Russian culture and folk-inspired forms and melodies, but its chaotic percussive momentum challenged its audience. Stravinsky, for example, borrowed the bassoon introduction from a Lithuanian folk song titled “Tu, manu seserėlė”. But he added multiple instruments and heightened this melody with dissonant melodies, recurrent changes in meter and rhythmic syncopations.

I can imagine the audience at the premiere of the Rite Of Spring being stunned by the orchestra’s clash of sounds. After listening to it for the first time, I got shocked when The Augurs of Spring, Dances of the Young Girls began. This work had so much power, violence, and changing rhythms that I was not prepared for it.

This piece relies heavily on rhythm as it leads almost all the parts. Even though the orchestral size of The Rite Of Spring is enormous, sometimes the rhythm is not played by percussion instruments but by other instruments, especially strings. In the Sacrificial Dance as well as The Dance of Young Girls, the orchestra’s percussive nature can be heard.

The rhythm sometimes evokes an African/Oceanic sound, as at the start of the Ritual of Abduction. Don’t forget that this piece was written at the height of African and Oceanian colonization. During the colonial period, there was a cultural clash that caused some artists to create art that didn’t resonate with previous creations. In a previous post, I discussed the importance of polyphony in Polynesia, which had a large French population. I wonder how much this influenced Stravinsky in the Rite Of Spring.

Creatively speaking, the piece possesses a lot of originality. Stravinsky layers a variety of melodies and rhythms on top of each other, creating what some would call noise. Yet ultimately, I believe this is a sonorous experience that requires dozens of listens to understand how each instrument fits into the music.

As I listened to the entire piece, I found it to be more enjoyable than I initially expected. What I enjoyed more than the rhythmic asymmetries, the dissonances, and the layers of ostinatos played simultaneously was the surprise element. Stravinsky played with the listener’s expectations and never let the music settle in a safe place, even though there are repetitions (especially underlying chords). After the listener becomes comfortable with a sonority, there is a twist, just like a plot twist in a narrative, and everything is new again.

As a result of this unexpected element, I understand why the audience at the premiere was shocked and furious. Apparently, it was the surprise, and I believe it was a loud one, that drove people crazy, even leading to the conductor, Pierre Monteux, admitting that “everything available was tossed in our direction” (Jones, n.d.). But this led me to raise a question.

Since when has music not shocked people? Almost since I was born, I recall tv shows, movies, and exhibitions that shocked the public. Music, however, does not seem to have shocked audiences as much. Does this mean that music is becoming less experimental? Is it because the audience is just accustomed to ignoring things they don’t like? Perhaps the “Next” button on the music player is to blame. Nowadays, listeners are not “obligated” to sit in a theatre for 90 minutes to hear a piece they’ve never heard before. What will be the next musical rage?

References

Schwarm, B., n.d. The Rite of Spring | History, Composer, & Facts. [online] Encyclopedia Britannica. Available at: <https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Rite-of-Spring> [Accessed 11 November 2021].

Pbs.org. n.d. Stravinsky’s The Rite of Spring: Keeping Score | PBS. [online] Available at: <https://www.pbs.org/keepingscore/stravinsky-rite-of-spring.html> [Accessed 11 November 2021].

Jones, E., n.d. Stravinsky’s The Rite of Spring | Music 101. [online] Courses.lumenlearning.com. Available at: <https://courses.lumenlearning.com/suny-musicapp-medieval-modern/chapter/stravinskys-the-rite-of-spring/> [Accessed 11 November 2021].
