item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In the first exercise for a two-part experience, I aimed to compose something similar to what I heard…
item.content:encoded:
In the first exercise for a two-part experience, I aimed to compose something similar to what I heard from Bach and a more “traditional” invention. After reading about invention, I gathered some process rules that allow writing an invention.

  • Write a motif in one voice
  • The second voice repeats the motif in another octave
  • The first voice imitates the motif on the dominant
  • The second voice imitates the motif it played before but this time on the dominant
  • Then use parts or the whole motif in augmented, diminuted or inversed version while the other voice plays counterpoint
  • End in the tonic

Although I know these are not strict rules, I tried to apply the process here to help me compose faster and with fewer elements. I must say I liked this process. I started with a motif that is played in both voices on the tonic and on the dominant. I then passed to both voices playing a diminuted version of the motif and ending with the oboe playing an inversion while the bassoon plays an augmented motif.

You can download the Sibelius file here.

In my second exercise, I tried to apply a more rhythmic invention while using the marimba. As in the first exercise, I created a motif that is repeated and imitated by both voices. I didn’t feel the need to augment the motif since I got the sense that I would lose the rhythm of it, so I used a diminuted version of the motif in the marimba while the flute plays an inversion.

You can download the Sibelius file here.

item.title: Listening to Scott Joplin – Maple Leaf Rag
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Scott Joplin was a remarkable composer who was able to combine African musical influences with classical music from…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • Scott Joplin was a remarkable composer who was able to combine African musical influences with classical music from Europe.
  • Syncopation adds variety and forward movement to music, making it feel faster even when the tempos aren’t.
  • The I-V progression is useful for conveying comfort and familiarity.

When researching for black composers I came across Scott Joplin, whom, I must admit, I didn’t know much of his work. Although I had heard some ragtime music before, I was far from knowing what exactly makes a ragtime song and how important it was to modern popular music.

Joplin’s History

Scott Joplin was born in northeastern Texas in 1867 or 1868, one of the first generation of African Americans born after slavery was abolished. His father used to be a slave, but his mother was born free. Both of Scott’s parents were performers, and he and his siblings grew up surrounded by music, primarily African traditional music performed by slaves.

Scott’s mother recognized his interest in music and was able to find him a free music teacher in exchange for housework. Julius Weiss, a German immigrant who, according to other students, was a follower of the European musical heritage with a special fondness for opera, was his teacher. Scott Joplin’s music owed a great deal to this. A descendant of an African slaver was not supposed to get a formal education, much less musical education. However, it was because of Weiss that he was able to understand piano technique, music theory, and, most crucially, European musical knowledge such as opera (Berlin, nd.).

The role of Joplin in Rag music

There is no doubt that Scott Joplin’s music took on the fresh feel it had because of the convergence of African and European music. He combined the syncopation of Afro-American folk music with the harmonization and marching tempos of 19th-century European romanticism to form the ultimate combination (Jasen & Tichenor, 1989). As a result, this led him to ragtime.

According to Grove Music Online, ragtime is “a style of popular music that flourished from the mid-1890s to 1918. Its main identifying trait is its ragged—i.e., syncopated—rhythm” (Berlin, 2013).

Joplin was known for his rags, particularly Maple Leaf Rag. Although it was not the first rag to be published, it was one of the most influential compositions in establishing ragtime as the first African-American music style to be widely adopted, earning him the title of King of Ragtime.

The Maple Leaf Rag and many other Joplin’s rags are considered Classic Rags. By “classic” we consider that the rag has a structure that “has three or four sections, each featuring a different 16-measure musical theme, or melody. In turn, these equal sections are divided into four lines of four measures each. Once a theme is played through, it is generally repeated immediately; in certain cases, it reappears later in the piece.” (The Library of Congress, Classic Rag).

Maple Leaf Rag is a good example of a Classic Rag since it not only follows the usual AABBACCDD pattern, is in duple meter, and has significant syncopation in the melody, but it is also very well thought out. To perform this composition successfully, you’ll need a developed pianistic talent.

Scott’s publisher, John Stark, believed his publications were as good as best classical music, and he promoted his view in elaborate ads. “Why are the Stark Music Co’s Rags called Classic? This is the reason: They are intellectual musical thoughts grounded in the emotional principle of humanity.” (The Library of Congress, Classic Rag).

My listening of Maple Leaf Rag

This composition drew my attention since Joplin defines the rhythm, speed, and atmosphere of the music from the first bar. He doesn’t build up any anticipation, and there aren’t many opportunities for both hands to rest. After playing this rag, I can image a pianist becoming really fatigued.

However, I believe that the absence of build-up, along with the melody’s powerful syncopation, results in a danceable and incredibly catchy music. At the same time, for individuals who are used to classical music and marches, the continuous simple bass progression (which is usually an I-V progression) provides a very familiar and comforting feel.

Philosophically, I believe the contrast between the syncopated melody and the structured bass reflects Joplin’s position in the artistic culture of the period. On the one hand, having been raised in an African musical background, he came from a culture where syncopated percussion beats are very prominent and where rhythm is vital to making people dance and interact with music. On the other hand, he was given formal classical training that allowed him to learn how the best European classical composers composed their works. The Maple Leaf Rag and others demonstrate that he learned from both cultures and passed them on to the composition.

You can clearly hear the syncopation and the I-V progression in Maple Leaf Rag’s first bars in the A section, where the bass line plays a steady rhythm, while the melody plays a syncopated rhythm. The syncopation is prominent in the song throughout.

Another key point to note is that, like previous classical composers, Joplin knew how to generate tension and release it. My past hearing of folk African music led me to believe that it was heavily reliant on repetition rather than dramatic moments. In bars 7-9, you can sense the tension building up.

In the B section, Joplin inserts chromatism to give the music a fresh perspective and, in my opinion, to instill the composition with some of his musical understanding.

The modulation from Ab Major to Db Major at the beginning of the C section and back to Ab at the beginning of the D section, especially the last one, is done quite smoothly. Although the modulation to the subdominant is a common ragtime modulation, I feel Joplin handled it in a fluid manner to once again demonstrate his abilities.

Another aspect of this music that I found intriguing is the triumphal finale, which has a counter motion between the voices and a large chord that eventually allows the pianist to rest after demonstrating his abilities.

Upon hearing Scott Joplin and reading about him, I concluded that he always fought for recognition. Despite the fact that Rags were not considered high-quality music, he had a formal musical education. I believe that confrontation is what caused his pieces to be considered so well-written, timeless, and a template for other styles that grew from it, including jazz.

After having studied both Joseph Bologne and Scott Joplin I find their similarities and differences very insightful. Both came from one musical background and were later exposed to another. But it did not impact them in the same way. The novelty and merge of cultures I was expecting, was more evident in Joplin’s music. My point is not that one is better or more relevant than the other. The two composers were inspirations and essential to composers who came after them. But when you think of music as an evolving landscape of different artistic viewpoints, I believe Joplin played a significant role in showing composers that you could mix them all and create beautiful pieces of music.

References

Berlin, E.A., Scott Joplin: Brief Biographical Sketch. Edward A. Berlin. Available at: https://www.edwardaberlin.com/scott_joplin__brief_biographical_sketch___33423.htm [Accessed November 3, 2021].

Jasen, D.A. & Tichenor, T.J., 1989. Rags and Ragtime: A musical history, New York: Dover.

Berlin, E.A., 2013. Ragtime. Grove Music Online. Available at: https://www-oxfordmusiconline-com.ucreative.idm.oclc.org/grovemusic/view/10.1093/gmo/9781561592630.001.0001/omo-9781561592630-e-1002252241. [Accessed November 3, 2021].

The Library of Congress, Classic Rag. The Library of Congress. Available at: https://www.loc.gov/item/ihas.200035813/ [Accessed November 4, 2021].

item.title: Listening to Joseph Bologne, Chevalier de Saint-Georges – Violin Concerto No. 9 in G Major, Op. 8
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: There are black composers who don’t get the attention they deserve, and Joseph Bologne is one of them…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • There are black composers who don’t get the attention they deserve, and Joseph Bologne is one of them
  • I couldn’t fiind an African inspired sound in his works, maybe because of his European education
  • I find descending notes pleasing, once again

One thought occurred to me while I was searching for music to listen to. What is the reason for the scarcity of well-known African classical composers? I couldn’t think of one, and a quick Google search reveals that the first dozen names that come up are all white men. I recognize that my lack of knowledge stems primarily from my western culture, so I set out to find black composers, which I am glad I did.

One of the articles I read was from classicfm.com entitled “9 Black composers who changed the course of classical music history”. The first featured composer is Joseph Bologne, Chevalier de Saint-Georges.

Joseph Bologne was born to a wealthy plantation owner and his Senegalese slave mistress in Basse-Terre, Guadaloupe, in 1745. He received the best education his father could afford during the family’s move to France and grew into an exceptionally gifted student. He had professional training, as evidenced by his extensive work list, which includes a number of comedic operas, symphonies and concertos, as well as chamber works (Banat, 2001).

Despite his pejorative nickname of The Black Mozart (also known as The Other Mozart), I find myself wondering if it shouldn’t be the other way around. Joseph Bologne is regarded as one of the greatest composers of the 18th century, according to Marlon Daniel. He was known to frequent salons as a guest of the French nobility, including those of queen Marie Antoinette, who was an accomplished singer herself. He influenced Franz Joseph Haydn, François-Joseph Gossec, Carl Stamitz, and, most notably, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, making him a leader rather than a follower of trends in the musical evolution of his century (Daniel, 2021).

His work was innovative since his earlier compositions, according to a New York Times article. “The six-string quartets of his Opus 1 were among the first in that genre to be written in France. His three sonatas for keyboard and violin (Op. 1a) feature those instruments as equals, breaking away from the Baroque tradition of basso continuo, which was still very much in vogue” (Balter, 2020).

Despite how innovative Bologne’s work may have sounded after listening to his violin concertos, my mind constantly tells me that he sounds a lot like some of his contemporaries. This, I believe, is a case of knowledge bias.

His Violin Concerto No. 9 in G Major, Op. 8 is one of my favourite works. I was struck by the three movements’ energy and rhythm, as well as the motifs he created. I couldn’t find a free score for this piece, but they can easily compete with other well-known motifs, in my humble and naive opinion. Why hasn’t his music been used in an advertisement commercial?

The second movement, Largo, is one of my favourites. Despite the fact that it is a slower movement, I consider it to be a continuation of the first movement’s accentuated rhythm. The syncopation provides a solid sound of descending notes in the first minute, which I find pleasing. In fact, I find this movement to be quite contemporary. While listening to him, I noticed parallels with Nicolas Britell’s, in my opinion, amazing Succession Tv Show soundtrack, particularly the Adagio in C Minor I show below.

In the end, I was thrilled about this discovery. I’m not qualified to say whether Joseph Bologne was a better composer than Mozart, but after hearing some of his works, I believe he deserves at least more credit.

References

Banat, G., 2001. Saint-Georges [Saint-George], Joseph Bologne, Chevalier de.. [online] Oxford University Press. Available at: https://www-oxfordmusiconline-com.ucreative.idm.oclc.org/grovemusic/view/10.1093/gmo/9781561592630.001.0001/omo-9781561592630-e-0000024316 [Accessed 27 October 2021].

Daniel, M., 2021. THE MUSIC OF JOSEPH BOLOGNE CHEVALIER DE SAINT-GEORGES. [ebook] Tafelmusik. Available at: https://www.tafelmusik.org/downloads/Tafelmedia/joseph-bologne-digital-booklet.pdf [Accessed 27 October 2021].

Balter, M., 2020. His Name Is Joseph Boulogne, Not ‘Black Mozart’. [online] Nytimes.com. Available at: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/22/arts/music/black-mozart-joseph-boulogne.html [Accessed 27 October 2021].

item.title: Listening to Beach Boys – God Only Knows
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Despite not being a huge fan of the Beach Boys, I’ve always enjoyed this song, mostly because it…
item.content:encoded:
Despite not being a huge fan of the Beach Boys, I’ve always enjoyed this song, mostly because it doesn’t seem like a typical love song. But I’ve never given any thought to how this song’s melody and harmony were created.

I chose to explore this piece after reading this quote when researching Bach’s fugues.

God Only Knows is regarded as one of The Beach Boys’ best songs and is adored by many musicians, including Paul McCartney who admitted this is one of his favourite songs. (Paul McCartney Comments, n.d.) Brian Wilson and Tony Asher wrote it for the Pet Sounds album with the goal of moving The Beach Boys away from a mainstream boyband sound and musically challenging the Beatles (Whatley, 2021). Paul McCartney later admitted that God Only Knows and the Pet Sounds inspired Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band. So this creative battle was won by all of us.

I believe the song’s theme is about the end of a relationship and the doubts that follow it. The hesitation in the opening lyrics “I may not always love you” distinguishes this song from other love songs. Throughout the lyrics and music, there is a sense of ambiguity, with a really weak tonal centre (Scott, 2019). As David Bennett’s video shows, the music modulates multiple times, and there are many reversed chords, so the sound never feels stable.

I read various analyses of this song, and while I think the music harmony is beautifully composed, I’m going to concentrate on melody and counterpoint because these concepts are covered in this section of the course.

The opposing motion between the vocal melody and the bass is the first fascinating melodic design I recognized. As I explained below, there’s a lively conversation going on between the two voices, with one going down and the other going up, and vice – versa. Even when they appear to be heading in the same direction, as in bar 3 of this example, they quickly diverge in bar 4. I believe this was written with the goal of drawing attention to the ambiguity and leaving the listener in the dark about what to expect.

Another section that sparked my curiosity was the bridge or brake, in which the keyboards and flute play a short instrumental passage that repeats the preceding opposite motion, but in a much more pronounced manner.

This bridge introduces a three-voice counterpoint that I’ve always found fascinating. I did my best to transcribe as accurately as I could, so it’s not perfect, but it allowed me to understand how the three voices work together to form triads, and how they mostly move in thirds and sixth intervals.

The music comes to a close with a round that I discussed in a previous entry.

Overall, I believe I enjoy this song more now that I am fully aware of the incredible labour that went into the melody and the blending of all voices. I see some parallels with Bach’s work, but I think I need to learn more about Bach’s music to really see how they might be related.

item.title: Project 11 – Inventing free counterpoint
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: During this project, I had to practice composing counterpoints for two instruments. There were two parts to the…
item.content:encoded:
During this project, I had to practice composing counterpoints for two instruments. There were two parts to the brief. With exercises 1 and 2, one of the instruments is already provided in the briefing, and the challenge is to compose a counterpoint for it. The task in exercises 3 and 4 is to compose two tunes with contrasting characters.

The workbook states that any tuning percussion instrument and woodwind instrument may be used. In order to get more familiar with tuned percussion, I decided to use them in all exercises.

You can download all Sibelius files here.

Exercise 1

With this exercise, the top melody was provided and I was asked to compose the bottom melody. As I looked at the written melody for the first time, I noticed that it had long notes, mirims, and crochets, so I decided to use mostly quavers and semiquavers to have a nice rhythmic contrast. I also took advantage of the opportunity to contrast the dynamics, sometimes having the vibraphone play higher than the flute.

Exercise 2

Here, the bottom part was given, and I composed the top melody. With the first three bars of my melody, I worked with the staccato from the flute by adding semiquavers, resulting in an interaction between the two instruments. In the next three bars, I made the marimba melody follow the descending flute melody, but with fast notes to emphasize the different melodies. The marimba contrasts with the flute in the last three bars by going up while the flute continues to go down.

Exercise 3

In the third exercise, I followed the workbook’s suggestion and started one melody later than the other, so the listener could more easily pick out the different voices. I developed a little theme that begins with the flute, then the tubular bells accompany it. Following this repetition, however, both melodies drift away. With a wave-shaped melody, the flute is more unstable, with a descending melody in bar 3 and an ascending melody until bar 5. In the meantime, the tubular bells are more stable, using almost always the same rhythm except for bar 7 when they take the opportunity of the calmer flute to express themselves.

Exercise 4

Similarly to the previous exercise, I tried to start one melody after another, while the instruments followed a similar theme. I could see how this theme could be used in different ways if it were a longer composition. Thus, for example, the xylophone plays two notes on the first part of the theme while the bassoon plays staccato over the same notes. However, after this repetition, the melodies go the opposite way. Generally, they move oppositely, except in the last bar when both move down and up to the final F.

item.title: Reflections on Assignment 3
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Moving from monophonic to polyphonic music, in my opinion, was a significant step forward in terms of both…
item.content:encoded:
Moving from monophonic to polyphonic music, in my opinion, was a significant step forward in terms of both complexity and creativity.

I had the opportunity to write for three instruments in this assignment, which proved to be more difficult than I anticipated, especially considering I had to write separate melodies for each of them. I can now better appreciate how great composers like Bach were able to compose in masterful harmony when they used 4 or more voices.

My hearing and analysis of rounds, descants, and, especially, polyphony, I believe, aided me in better understanding how voices might be written in harmony but with differing melodies.

About Assignment 3

As I previously stated, I found this task to be far more challenging than the prior two. Considering three instruments, each with their distinct melodies and “personalities,” brought a level of difficulty I hadn’t anticipated. However, I believe that this additional complexity will be advantageous in the long run as assignment tasks become longer and include more instruments.

In terms of notation, I made an effort to avoid some of the faults I made in earlier assignments, such as rhythmic spelling, correct beaming, and phrasing.

My ability to construct a two-minute composition and transpose the concepts I had in my head to a score surprised me. I wanted to compose a piece that put polyphony to work for the music rather than the other way around. The repeated theme and various small melodies throughout the music, I believe, made this polyphonic composition both familiar and fresh at the same time.

Being self-critical, I think this piece contains too many elements. As a result, I feel that I could turn this into a 4-minute musical piece that develops some of the ideas I wanted to include.

item.title: Assignment 3
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: My third task was to compose a work for three woodwind instruments in a mostly polyphonic approach. This…
item.content:encoded:
My third task was to compose a work for three woodwind instruments in a mostly polyphonic approach. This composition should last about two minutes and follow a predetermined structure (seen below), in which one begins with a triad, moves to another, and concludes with another.

You can find the final score here and listen to it below:

I had few questions after seeing example 45. Should the first triad last several bars? (If that’s the case, I’ll have to use different chords in the meanwhile, or it’ll sound stuck). Or is the example intended to be regarded as a chord progression that should be used throughout the piece?

My tutor assisted me with these questions by directing me to consider these triads as harmonic centres for the music.

With this in mind, I decided to use three triads, each representing a different essence of the music, resulting in a piece of music with three parts.

The Idea / Theme

After reflecting on my polyphonic studies, I came up with the idea for this composition. I listened to polyphonic music in three different styles: Renaissance, Baroque, and African/Polynesian polyphony. Because the assignment’s predetermined structure required three triads, I challenged myself to write a piece of music in three parts, each inspired by a different style of polyphonic music.

About the theme, this piece will be about a love triangle involving three instruments. After meeting and dancing in an African/Polynesian section, they progressed to the baroque section, where they fell in love, then finalized the dance with a passionate and harmonious section (Renaissance), showcasing their love for one another.

The Structure

The structure was mostly determined upon the development of the idea. This would be a straightforward story in which A leads to B, which leads to C. I wanted the music to begin rhythmically as if the instruments were dancing together and each had its own individuality. Then, in a more melodic section, the instruments repeat the motif as though they discover something in common and fall in love. Ending in harmony and love, each instrument repeats the same motif but then each plays its own melodic line while respecting the harmony of the others.

I decided to produce a piece in the key of C# major after studying pentatonic scales. The other triads and keys were chosen based on the least amount of note change between them.

The Motifs

As I had done with prior projects and assignments, I began playing around with the piano, hoping to find a theme that sounded good to me and would serve as a catapult for this composition. After a time, I came upon a motif that I really loved and decided to go a little deeper into it.

Because the song is divided into three distinct sections, I thought it would be fascinating if the same motif appeared in each section, but was played differently and by different instruments. This way, something would connect all three pieces.

This motif is performed subtly in semiquavers in the A section by the oboe.

The B section is played more explicitly and with quavers by the flute.

The motif is performed by the bassoon nearly in the background with crochets in the C section.

This division was quite helpful in enabling me to start writing each section quicker.

The Instruments

Flute, oboe, and bassoon were my natural choices for a woodwind trio. I chose these three instruments because I believe they complement each other in terms of timbre while remaining distinct enough for the listener to hear each one’s melody.

I listened to three pieces to gain a sense of how a trio of woodwinds works together and how other composers used these instruments.

One of the first instances I found of the three I selected to work with was Antonio Vivaldi’s Concerto for Flute, Oboe, and Bassoon in G Minor, RV 103. This composition didn’t particularly appeal to me, but it did teach me how much prominence the flute can have at times, as well as how the oboe and flute can sound good together without clashing, with the flute in a high register and the oboe in a middle and low register.

The Trio for Flute, Oboe, and Bassoon, Op. 86 by Röntgen was an excellent illustration of what I was attempting. Each instrument’s identity is respected alongside the melody, yet they also repeat each other. This adds a lot of depth to the music.

Pastorale for Wind Trio, Op. 147 by Darius Milhaud omits the flute but includes the clarinet. I was especially inspired by how wonderfully polyphony worked beginning in bar 24.

The composition

Section A Bars 1-9

I intended to portray more rhythmic and fast-paced music in this section. As a result, I employed semiquavers in all three instruments and staccato most of the time.

This section is in the key of B major, although it begins with a D#m triad. The B major triad is present in the second beat of the first bar to create the home triad.

The oboe and flute begin by playing nearly the identical melody with a 3rd, 5th, or 6th interval, but at bar 4 the flute begins to move from a quick staccato to a slower legato. Meanwhile, the bassoon plays a more danceable melody.

This section has the most triad changes, with the majority being B major, D# minor, F# major and G# minor.

This section ends with a VI – I, reintroducing the home triad and leading to the next triad.

Section B Bars 10-20

The music here shifts to a more elaborate yet slower paced approach. The speed is reduced to 70 quaver beats per minute, and the notes are predominantly quavers. In bar 11, the flute plainly states that the key signature has changed to C# major.

The home triad, like the first section, is played right at the start to express the feeling of the new home triad. This time, I stuck with the home triad for a little longer than in the first section, with inversions of the triad lasting two bars and the primary motif repeated by the three instruments.

In contrast to the preceding section, this one contains a clearly defined chord progression: I – IV – iii – V.

It ends with an I – IV, which leads to the next triad, that is expected to be the V: G# major.

Section C Bars 21-40

Despite the fact that the tempo remains constant, I wanted the music to feel slower and more harmonized. As a result, I utilized a lot of crochets, minims, and semibreves.

This section is in the key of Ab major. I wanted it to be in G# major scale, but I learned that G# major isn’t commonly used because it’s too complex for practical use, and that Ab major is a better option.

In contrast to the other sections, I do not explicitly tell the listener of the key change. Though I begin with the Ab major triad, it isn’t until the third beat of the second bar of this section (bar 22) that I reach an Ab major triad.

In the final part of this section I wanted to express pure polyphony, with each instrument adding their own melody one at a time, culminating with all three instruments playing distinct melodies until they rise to end in Ab major triad.

item.title: Listening & Researching Polyphony
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Polyphonic music is when two or more melodies are played at the same time, each with the same…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • Polyphonic music is when two or more melodies are played at the same time, each with the same relevance
  • It is not just a Western concept; it is found in a variety of cultures, each of which is distinct
  • Polyphonic music is more difficult to listen to than monophonic or homophonic music. Using a recurring theme through the voices is one method to make it easier to listen to
  • When there are more than 5 voices and melodies, it’s nearly impossible to distinguish them, and the experience becomes an aural one

Before I could listen to polyphonic music, I needed to define polyphony. There are three types of music textures: monophonic, homophonic, and polyphonic (Copland, Rich and Slatkin, 2011).

So far, I’ve largely studied monophonic music, which is music composed using a single tune. It does not imply that the music is limited to a single instrument or vocal. Monophonic music can feature percussion and many lines, but they all play the same melody at the same time.

Today’s contemporary popular music is predominantly homophonic. It means that a principal melody is accompanied by a chordal accompaniment. Generally, it is more pleasant to hear than monophonic music because the harmony is played in a way that elevates the main melody.

Polyphony is more challenging than the preceding two. It occurs when two or more melodies happen at the same moment but are unrelated to one another. One of the most distinguishing characteristics of polyphony is that it is difficult to discern which melody is the primary one because each has its own prominence.

I was reminded of a pop tune that contains all three types of musical textures. Come On Eileen by Dexys Midnight Runners makes it simple to understand the three principles. The song begins with a single violin playing in a monophonic texture. The sound then shifts to a homophonic texture, primarily in the chorus. Finally, in the bridge portion, all voices join together in a polyphonic texture with up to three melodies, as far as I can tell.

Proceeding to my listening of polyphonic music, I decided that it will consist of as many listenings as there are melodies, plus one. To do this, I will try to listen to each melody separately and then all of them together in one final listening.

Thomas Morley – April Is In My Mistress’ Face

This is a polyphonic composition of music for four voices (Soprano, Alto, Tenor, Bass), and it is one of the shortest English madrigals, published in 1594.

After a first listen, this music seems to me like a Christmas carol, despite the fact that there is nothing in the lyrics that leads in that direction except the “cold December” section. Speaking of the lyrics, this is not a cheerful love poem, and I believe the music reflects the protagonist’s disappointment.

The song starts with gentle rhythms but ascending melodic lines when describing April and June as metaphors for her beauty and the warmth of her eyes.

But as the song progresses towards the colder months, it becomes a little melancholy and deeper, with the vocals becoming lower in pitch and dynamics. September has lengthier notes and the melodies are more similar.

The most memorable section of the music occurs in December when the tune of “But in her heart” is repeated several times by all voices. This is foreshadowing the protagonist’s disappointment when he discovers she is as cold as December, and all voices get quieter and slower.

For me, the most exciting part is when the voices interact, and you can hear one voice starting at one point and another voice following up where the first left. This example below exemplifies how Thomas Morley considered this, employing quavers to interact amongst the voices, crotchets, and minims when the melodies are independent. This results in a lovely soundscape.

Although it is polyphonic music with individual melodies, there is some round counterpoint, as shown in the examples above and below. This can demonstrate that the composer is not limited to a single style.

Thomas Tallis – Spem in Alium

Because this is a 40-part motet, I did not follow the guideline of listening to it as many times as there are voices.

It was written about 1570 by Thomas Tallis for eight choirs of five voices each and is regarded as the greatest piece of English early music by certain commentators.

Writing polyphonic compositions is a complex job for the composer and a demanding one for the listener who tries to follow each melody alone. This is especially true for music with more than three or four melodies, so one can only imagine how impressive it is to write for 40 voices and over 11 minutes. An example of Tallis’s incredible work can be seen in the example below.

Concentrating on individual melodies proved difficult in this situation, so I just listened to Spem in Alium as a whole choir song. I must add that it greatly surprised me and gave me a hypnotic sense due to the aural movements of the choirs. Though it is widely assumed that Tallis intended his choirs to be placed in a horseshoe form, I can only imagine how magnificent it would be to hear it live, with all eight choirs positioned in a circle around you, creating a 360º experience.

This piece, in my opinion, can be separated into three parts.

  • The first choir begins with just a few voices being formed together, then the other chorus joins them in turn. It almost sounds like a round.
  • Then, after a brief time when all 40 voices are singing together, we see an inverted movement from the opening section, in which the choirs follow each other in reverse order.
  • It is in the final section, which is more like a conversation between choirs, where this piece makes full use of its complexity, jumping between voices as it moves from choir to choir until it ends with all choirs singing together.

Even though I didn’t find it boring, I thought the music was a bit longer than I would find interesting. Listening to it live would probably transmit the power and the spatial interactivity Tallis intended and keep it interesting for the whole 11 minutes of this piece.

Bach: Prelude and Fugue No.17 in Ab major, BWV 862

I was interested to listen how the polyphonic music developed from the renaissance era to the baroque. After reading some articles I found that Bach would be a great example of polyphonic baroque music, so I listened to a few of his fugues. The No.17 in Ab major was one the I liked most.

The polyphony of the late Baroque differed from that of the Renaissance: It was rooted in tonal harmony and characterized by an energetic, metrically conceived, driving rhythm (Hylton, 2005).

The start of the prelude really interested me because it was such a great way of opening a piece. It reminded me of some rock and heavy metal songs that start with triads in one guitar and a melody in another.

The theme of the prelude is repeated several times by both voices. Since polyphony can be hard to listen, this repetition of the main theme in one voice makes it sound familiar, while the other voice delivers a new and unexpected sound, making it fresh at the same time.

Even from the start is easy to find the differences from renaissance polyphony. More rhythm and more complexity.

Moving to the fugue, the new theme is clearly stated by repetition of the 4 voices, two in Ab major and two in Eb major.

I really like how the voices keep playing the main theme, specially when they rise for a perfect 4th or 5th as in the example below. It gives a really fresh and climatic tone to the music.

Also interesting is that in bar 11 starts a new melody that is repeated by three voices, separating by a perfect 5th and a perfect 4th. This adds again a freshness to the music, and Bach makes sure that although this piece is polyphonic and complex, there is always a familiar tune to be listened.

I find this type of polyphony more interesting than the previous examples I listened, perhaps because I find that the complexity of notes and rhythms add more colour and interest to the piece.

Polyphony of Dorze People

While researching polyphony, I came across this statement in the ‘Why do people sing?’ book.

Therefore, I decided to listen to some polyphony singing from the Dorze tribe in Ethiopia to see and understand the main differences between them and western polyphony.

There are two songs on this recording that I listened to:

  • Ritual song by young boys
  • Spinning song by young girls

The first one had a drone-like effect in one of the voices while the other voices sang a repeated theme. It’s a pretty rhythmic tune, but it’s also incredibly repetitive, with the same theme running throughout.

The second song appears to be a three-part polyphony, with one high-pitched solo melody, another group melody, and a low-pitched rhythmical melody. This one appears to be more sophisticated than the last one and more enjoyable to listen to.

The biggest difference between this song and the ones I previously evaluated is that each voice is sung with a specific function in mind, such as a rhythmic voice or a harmonising voice.

Tautai Taora Ofrai (Leeward Islands)

Little did I know that Polynesia was one of the first places on earth to develop polyphonic music. Europeans discovered Polynesia’s long tradition of polyphonic music in the 18th century. This discovery was a shocking one for European musicians, who believed that polyphony, as an attribute of a more advanced musical civilization, could have been only a product of the Christian monastery (Jordania, 2011).

This is one of the examples of recorded Polynesian polyphony.

I got the same feeling after listening to Tautai Taora Ofrai as I did after listening to Dorze People’s polyphony. It’s a song with a lot of rhythms, but it’s also very repetitive.

Apart from that, I found this music to have a structure, with three parts separated by a drone from one of the voices.

Another difference I noticed between the two listenings is that there are more voices (at least four different melodies) and that they don’t appear to have a specific role, but rather their own melodies that are distinct from the other voices.

Finally, I’d want to share one anti-polyphony viewpoint that startled me. As in the video below, polyphony was described by Vincenzo Galilei as “a big mess of incoherent imperfections”. Despite the fact that I believe these statements to be harsh, I can see why Vicenzo Galilei wrote them. Polyphony is difficult to listen to and, if not properly done, can quickly devolve into a big mess.

References

Copland, A., Rich, A. and Slatkin, L., 2011. What to listen for in music. New York, N.Y: Signet Classic.

Jordania, J., 2011. Why do people sing?. Tbilisi [Georgia]: Logos, p.20.

Hylton, J., 2005. Comprehensive choral music education. Taipei: Pearson Education Taiwan Ltd.

The goal of this project was to create three different melodic lines that combined to make a little polyphony. The same triad chord should be used to begin and end the song.

I started with three flutes, as one of the coursework examples suggested, but after experimenting with different melodies, I realized the three voices would sound too similar, so I switched to a woodwind trio of Flute, Oboe, and Bassoon.

This little polyphony was written in a different way from the rest of my projects. I composed vertically, which means I worked on all three melodies at the same time, one bar at a time. I began by deciding on a key (G minor), then came up with a chord progression that I liked: Gm – Eb – Bb – Gm. With these factors in mind, I began each bar with the triads of each chord and designed the melodies in each bar to connect the triads.

This way of work was interesting since I didn’t have a sense of a final melody while I worked, but when I got to the end, I could clearly hear the many melodies. I then made some adjustments to ensure that the voices don’t clash when played simultaneously, particularly with the 2nd and 7th intervals, which sound dissonant.

item.title: Project 9 – Descants
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In this project, I was tasked with writing a descant for three of the five tunes provided. My…
item.content:encoded:
In this project, I was tasked with writing a descant for three of the five tunes provided. My decision was determined after listening to the five songs and selecting the three that I liked the best.

After doing some reading on Descants, I tried to incorporate what I learned into my exercises. I used counter-motion, tried to employ thirds and sixths most of the time, and kept the descant rhythmically distinct from the main theme. In addition, I added the descant above the melody.

Exercise 1 – Käki Se Kukkoo

You can download the Sibelius file here.

The main melody made me think that it could be played by the bassoon since in my research I found that the bassoon isn’t stuck to playing low notes, but can play high notes as well. It then occurred to me I’d seen a video of Debussy’s La fille aux Cheveux de lin being performed by bassoon and harp. As a result, I wrote the descant for harp.

Debussy in Vienna – Bassoon and Harp

Even when the harp is played very quickly, it remains delicate and beautiful; therefore, I used quavers almost exclusively in contrast to the main melody crochets. In this piece, I used relatively little contrary motion since I felt that the two instruments contrasted enough and sometimes they even completed each other, as you the example below.

Exercise 2 – Ayçem

You can download the Sibelius file here.

I find the bassoon and oboe to be very celebratory instruments, as I explained before in my log. Because this tune sounded festive, I chose the oboe in contrast to the really high pitched piccolo. As I thought the piece needed some bass, I included the bass drum.

Despite the fact that both the descant and the main theme use quavers and semiquavers, I don’t think they clash, since I tried to respect the rhythm of each melody.

Exercise 3 – Na haste do castanheiro

You can download the Sibelius file here.

I chose this tune because I liked it, but I also knew it beforehand, so I tried to have fun. As the music always sounded like a church sound, I decided to go with the organ for the main theme and the choir to sing the descant.

For this exercise, I focused on the rhythmic differences of each tune, except for the finale, which I wanted to be memorable. Because of that, they both have the same rhythm, but they move in opposite directions.

Reflection

With the descant, I had considerably more fun than I did with the rounds. The main difference is that melody is more about improvisation and novelty, opposite to the more structured thought processes of a round. However, I find that both methods help me get a better sense of vertical composition.

item.title: Listening to Descants
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Descant is a form of counterpoint, but usually is introduced after the melody is established and sang above…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • Descant is a form of counterpoint, but usually is introduced after the melody is established and sang above the melody
  • Descants usually are written in the 3rd and 6th notes of the notes played by the melody
  • Although is not used in modern music, I believe it did not disappeared, just evolved

My first step was to look up the definition of Descants. Merriam-Webster defines it as “a superimposed counterpoint to a simple melody sung typically by some or all of the sopranos”.

One of the definitions in The Oxford Dictionary of Music is “In modern hymn singing, a freely written or improvised soprano part added to a hymn tune while the tune itself is sung by the rest of the choir or by the congregation.” (Kennedy, Kennedy and Rutherford-Johnson, 2012).

In my own words, it occurs when composers introduce a melody over an already established tune and both perform flawlessly.

But one question arose: what is the difference between counterpoint and descant, given that both are melodies over melodies?

I struggled to find an answer to my question, but after some thought, I believe a descant is a type of counterpoint. However, there are two significant differences between regular and descant counterpoints:

  • A descant is introduced when the melody has been well established, either via repetition or by being a popular melody, whereas conventional counterpoint can be used at any time. As a result, descants are frequently introduced near the end of a hymn, as as in ‘Hark! the Herald Angels Sing,’ as shown below.
  • A descant is a melody that is placed above the melody by high-pitched singers or instruments (What is a… Descant?, 2021). A normal counterpoint can be placed either above or below the melody.

The majority of the examples I discovered were from choral works. As a result, my listening will be primarily focused on two of these works.

Come, all ye faithful arr. David Willcocks

The descant is only introduced in minute 2:16 of this Christmas carol, proving my claim that descants are introduced after the main melody is well established. One of the most fascinating aspects of the descant is illustrated in the image below. Both melodies have a contrary motion, so when one goes up, the other goes down. When they appear to clash (in the “of” passage), the descant descends to its lowest note, while the main melody ascends to its highest tone. This, together with the use of thirds and sixths, makes a nice contrast.

Hark! the Herald Angels Sing (Willcocks) – Bethel Festival Choir and Orchestra

The descant appears at the end of the song, at the 2:46 mark. And with this song, I discovered another reason to create a descant: it can give the music an apotheotic ending, as I demonstrate below. Look at how the main melody is largely made up of crochets and only utilizes 5 notes, whereas the descant melody is mostly made up of quavers and uses 8 different notes in a descending – descending – ascending form. This gives the song a powerful ending.

Later, I came across this video in which one individual I couldn’t name, claims that the descant was a noble kind of art that is now extinct.

I would argue that if the descant is defined by an improvised line spoken over a known tune, it is not lost but rather moved from the vocal to the guitar. Guitar solos, in my opinion, are the modern equivalent of descant. I understand that this may offend some purist music theorists, but if you think of music as an evolving form of art, it makes sense.

Consider the Merriam-Webster definition (a superimposed counterpoint to a simple melody sung typically by some or all of the sopranos) and consider the guitar solo as a superimposed counterpoint over a simple melody, usually played by higher-pitched sounds and usually introduced after the main melody is established.

There are a million examples of guitar solos, improvised or not, over a melody, but I think the 1950s blues, when the electric guitar became popular, is one fantastic example of how the vocal descant transferred to the guitar solo, or should I say guitar descant.

References

Kennedy, J., Kennedy, M. and Rutherford-Johnson, T., 2012. The Oxford Dictionary of Music (6th Edition). 6th ed. Oxford University Press.

Classical Music. 2021. What is a… Descant?. [online] Available at: <https://www.classical-music.com/features/articles/what-a-descant/> [Accessed 29 September 2021].

item.title: Listening to Stevie Wonder – Overjoyed
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Use sounds other than traticional acoustic instruments to convey an atmosphere Keep the melody interesting by beginning notes…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • Use sounds other than traticional acoustic instruments to convey an atmosphere
  • Keep the melody interesting by beginning notes just before or after they should begin
  • Surprise the audience with key changes

For me, Stevie Wonder is an acquired taste. I didn’t love his music as much when I was younger, but as I’ve gotten older, I’ve come to appreciate and admire how he created such beautiful songs.

Despite the fact that his album Songs In The Key Of Life is widely regarded as his masterpiece, one of his songs that I particularly enjoy listening to is Overjoyed. I’m sure there’s a lot of literature devoted to describing how Stevie Wonder composed his songs, but I wanted to understand for myself why I appreciate this song so much and what composing talents he used to achieve such a wonderful sound.

Previous note: I will not study the lyrics because I am more interested in melody, harmony, and rhythm at the moment.

The song begins with a piano and guitar accompanied by strange sounds. Stevie Wonder refers to it as Environmental Percussion, and it consists of natural noises such as birds, crushed leaves, and stones dropped in a pond (Harrington, 1985). In fact, these water drops can be found throughout the song in the backbeat.

It’s hard to tell which key the music starts in since it goes from C# Major 6 to C7 to B Major 7 and then back to C7. It repeats once again, but instead of going up in the last chord, it goes down to Bb.

This intro is such an odd way to begin a song because it doesn’t really inform you what to anticipate. When the line is descending, the listener expects it to continue descending, but the chords rise, and when it repeats, the expectation is that it will rise in the last chord, but it continues to descend. This up and down uncertainty, as well as the sounds of nature, distinguishes this song from many others.

When the verse begins, the chords and voice shift to Eb, the song’s key. The final Bb chord of the intro now makes sense because it is the dominant of the Eb.

The verse is an I-vi-ii-V progression, which is quite common, and the vocal melody is also quite simple. With such an odd beginning, you wouldn’t expect such a straightforward but wonderful verse.

One thing I realized is that if you listen closely to Steve’s vocal melody, he begins slightly before the rhythm, as shown in the example below. This syncopation is a subtle but crucial rhythm decision in my opinion. It appears that the singer is propelling the music ahead with vowels rather than consonants, as one might expect.

When there is a repetition, Stevie Wonder goes to unexpected places, as he did in the intro. When the listener expects an ii (F minor) in the I-vi-ii-V progression in the second part of the verse, the music modulates to a C major scale, and the chords go to an F major 7 and then to a G major 7, and the B part of the verse begins in C major.

This game of not giving the listener what he expects is not new, but it works marvellously when it is effectively crafted.

When the listener expects a repetition in this B section of the verse, the music moves to another area. In this case, we expect to stay in the major key, but the third chord is a C minor, so the key shifts to a minor.

Following the verse, the melody gracefully transitions to the chorus, with a chromatic rise to a new chord: Ab Major. The melody drops through G – F – Eb – D, which is on the Eb major scale, so I don’t believe the music modulates to a new key signature.

This chorus is particularly fascinating since the chords he uses to advance to the chorus are also used to decrease in the chorus. That’s intriguing because Stevie Wonder, once again, plays with the listener’s expectations. He went up with Bb – C -D – Eb – F -G then down with G – F – Eb – D, therefore the following note should be C, but instead, he changes the chorus to C#. It’s only for a moment, but it’s a pleasant surprise. But the surprise doesn’t stop there; the chorus modulates to a new key a whole tone above, creating a fantastic climax.

The song returns to the intro and the verse, but when the music moves to the chorus again, the melody begins in the A (just as it did in the second chorus). At this point, the listener may wonder if the chorus can get any higher. It does. Again, we modulate to a whole tone above, reaching the peak of the song.

As expected, the song culminates with the root note Eb after the chorus. There are no surprises at the end of the song.

I knew this song was beautifully crafted even before I analyzed it, but I had no idea it had so many details like the water sound, the syncopation in the verse, or the major/minor key modulations. I genuinely believe that this analysis helped me understand how to keep a song engaging without making it appear overly difficult.

References

Harrington, R., 1985. Records. [online] The Washinton Post. Available at: https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1985/09/10/records/ba3caa0f-72cd-4618-b722-2c840890522e/ [Accessed 23 September 2021].

item.title: Listening to Rounds
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: A round is a musical composition in the form of a canon, and the melody is constructed in…
item.content:encoded:
A round is a musical composition in the form of a canon, and the melody is constructed in a way that produces a counterpoint when various performers or instruments begin it at different times. It is known as a “perpetual canon” since its ending works along with the opening.

I listened to dozens of rounds because they are typically easy and fun to listen to. I chose a few that appealed to me the most.

The Great Bells of Oseney

This is a three-part round from 1609, but I couldn’t discover any further information about it.

This is a pretty simple round, but it’s useful to understand how three voices are used to produce triads most of the time, particularly in the first and end beats.

Hava Nashira

A three-part round in Hebrew from the 15th century that is frequently assigned to Johannes Ockeghem, despite the lack of strong evidence of that.

The intriguing aspect of this round is that all voices have the identical note durations in the first two bars, resulting in a tremendous harmonizing sound. This pattern is disrupted in the third and fourth bars by the introduction of quavers, which creates a nice surprise.

Hey, ho, Nobody Home

A three-part round in the minor key that dates back to at least 1609.

Typically, rounds are amusing or joyous songs, but this one is a lament sung in the D Minor scale. In contrast to the other rounds, this one employs a lot of quavers in between the chords, resulting in a more nuanced music. Another intriguing element is that the melody ends in the supertonic rather than the tonic, producing a sense of incompleteness and perpetualness.

Dona Nobis Pacem

This is a popular Latin three-part round that is frequently assigned to Palestrina, however some contend that it was written by Mozart.

What strikes me the most about this round is that, except the first two bars, all voices are really close together. They even end all three on the same note. When sang collectively, I believe this produces a more powerful sound, but I don’t believe the listener can follow the voices independently, which is one of the most interesting things in rounds.

Go to Joan Glover

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uSCeV7WH2ms

This is a quick four-part round from 1609.

What I found remarkable about this round is the rhythm that all four voices repeat, almost always employing the triad. I think it’s incredibly danceable, and when sung in a group, it may make for a very energetic round.

Bona Nox

This famous round is in A major for four voices by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

I was curious to hear a Mozart round, and I loved how he employed the Minims and crochets to keep the bass notes sustained. When listening to the melody with just one voice, it’s difficult to tell if there’s a top melody and a bass background, but when all voices are heard combined, it’s clear that there is.

Once, twice, thrice I Julia try’d

Of course, I couldn’t leave Henry Purcell out of this round (pun intended).

My favorite Purcell round was this one, which was humourous in style and delightful in how the voices sang “so kiss my arse” properly, accentuating each note with great force and confidence.

Although the majority of the examples I listened to were made more than a century ago, I remembered two instances from recent music that demonstrate that rounds are alive and well and may be employed in a modern context.

The most well-known is the final section of The Beach Boys’ – God only knows. I recently watched Paul Mccartney’s documentary “McCartney 3, 2, 1,” in which he admits that Brian Wilson is one of his favorite harmony composers, and you can tell that this round is quite well composed.

Another song from the musical Rent that came to mind is “Will I?” from the musical Rent. Musicals, in my opinion, are a terrific platform for writing rounds because you can work with different vocal tones, portrayed by different characters, and so create a highly dynamic song.

About Assignment 2

The assignment took far longer than I thought once again. According to the OCA assignment introduction, this should take about 3 hours, yet it took me about 3 days. Despite the amount of time it took me, I am quite pleased with the outcome. I was able to incorporate my idea for this work into the score, generating two contrasting parts for the two clarinet registers – chalumeau and clarion.

The four basic elements of music are rhythm, melody, harmony, and tone colour (Copland, Rich and Slatkin, 2011). Because this section of the course is about melody, I concentrated on the melodic rather than the rhythmic aspects of the piece. I wanted at least one memorable section of the tune that the listener would recognize immediately when it was repeated. With the main motif, I believe I was successful.

Although I liked creating for untuned percussion, I must say that composing for a pitched instrument was far more enjoyable. However, I must admit that the rhythm aspect was crucial, particularly in terms of not being stuck with a time signature or employing pauses as rhythmic alterations.

On the downside, I believe I could improve some aspects of my composition. I think the music sometimes goes to predictable places rather than surprising the listener with unexpected notes. In the next assignment, I must avoid this. I also believe I rushed several parts of the composition when the music needed to rest. Due to the 2-minute time limit, this was necessary.

Overall, I’m looking forward to hearing what my tutor thinks of this work and any ideas and adjustments he or she may have.

item.title: Assignment 2
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: As part of the second assignment, I had to write a composition for a solo woodwind instrument that…
item.content:encoded:
As part of the second assignment, I had to write a composition for a solo woodwind instrument that lasted between 1:30 and 2 minutes. The challenge of this composition is that I can use whichever scale I choose (it can be more than one scale), to take advantage of the instrument’s specific features and to respect its range.

You can find the final score here and listen to it below:

Just like in the first assignment, I thought it was beneficial to create an outline and get an idea of what I was trying to accomplish beforehand. Though it may seem counterproductive at first, the structure and the idea helped me stay focused and keep a coherent thought process.

The Idea / Theme

This piece will centre around a character that is mournful during the workweek and eccentric on the weekend. In a routine and boring job, weekdays become monotonous and boring, while weekends become exciting and fun.

Usually on Mondays you feel melancholy, Tuesday through Thursday are monotonous and regretful, followed by Friday and Saturday with euphoria, and finally Sunday turns slowly into melancholy again and you’re back on Monday.

The Structure

As soon as I had the idea, the structure made sense to me. First, there is an intro, followed by the main theme, and then there is a happy section. Revert to the main motif before ending the same way it began.

For the first two parts, the tempo would be slow, followed by a fast tempo for the third part, and then slowly decreasing for the final two parts.

The Motifs

My process for composing a motif was to play simple lines on the piano and to find one that sounds right to me. Inspiration overcame transpiration in this case. After some time, I began playing these four notes.

In spite of the simplicity of the melody, I liked the quaver/crochet rhythm, which gave me a sense of lull and monotony that I felt was appropriate for the B part. Although it feels like it is going up, it lacks the strength to stay up and goes down. Likewise, our character longs for the energy to accomplish something but returns to mourning.

After that, I discovered that the scale I wanted to work on would be the E harmonic minor, with the seventh diminished, which sounds exotic but at the same time lamenting.

The A part of the song has a similar motif to the B part, but to me, it feels more nostalgic, like someone is remembering the good old days (like the weekend).

Because the C part is festive, I knew right away that I needed to change the scale, but not by much because the character remains the same and I didn’t want to have a big contrast. I chose to use the Ukrainian minor scale in the key of C, which is one of the most widely used scales in Klezmer music. As I worked with this scale, I realized these are exactly the notes of the G harmonic minor scale. I found this scale very festive even though it is a minor scale, which goes against the common idea that minor scales are sad.

In the C part of the song, the motif is made up of quavers and semiquavers, enjoying the wonderful staccato the clarinet can produce.

The Clarinet

The clarinet is extremely versatile, and that’s why I chose it. With this piece, I wanted to push myself to explore both low and high registers while maintaining a cohesive line throughout. Clarinets have the broadest range of all woodwinds and can easily transition from pianissimo to fortissimo (Adler, 2002).

My research on the clarinet led me to these videos from Josh Plotner which explain, among other things, that the composer should avoid the Throat Tones register (from G4 to Bb4) due to its hollowness and weak sound. Although I tried to avoid these notes, it was difficult for me to eliminate them from the melody.

In the videos, it is also explained to avoid flutter tongue and use growl instead, since it sounds better.

Part I—Essential Writing for Clarinet
Part II—Advanced Writing for Clarinet

This document from the Young Music Makers of Dyfed offers some techniques for the clarinet, one of which caught my attention, which is breathing into the clarinet without playing any notes.

It is also advised to avoid the transition between B4 and Bb4, referred to as “the break,” due to its difficult transition that only experienced players can handle (Adler, 2002).

The Composition

Part A Bars 1-9

This section serves as a brief introduction and presents the first motif. The purpose of this section is to show the listener that the melody will stay in the Chalumeau register.

  • Bars 1-4 are slow notes establishing the scale
  • Bars 5-9 are the part A motif followed by a descending to end this part

Part B Bars 10-19

While the tempo remains the same, the time signature switches to 3/4 here, and the dynamics increase. As a result, the listener can feel the character’s discomfort and lament.

  • Bars 10-11 the main motif is presented and raised by one step
  • Bars 12-13 a variation of the motif going down and ending in the 5th
  • Bar 14 is a variation of the main motif
  • Bar 15 is a repetition of bar 11
  • Bar 16 is similar to bar 11 but with the extra QUAVER
  • Bars 17-19 the melody descends ending with a trill to the tonic

Part C Bars 20-43

In contrast to the previous two, this is the fastest section. Here, glissandos and growls are used to convey the feel of the parties and the exuberance of the weekend concept.

  • Bar 20 is a scale run ascending over two octaves
  • Bar 21-22 a glissando sustained and played fortissimo
  • Bars 23-24 a crescendo in dynamics and offbeat notes
  • Bars 25-27 is the part C motif and its variations
  • Bar 28 the triplets are descending
  • Bars 29-30 are another variation of the motif
  • Bars 31-32 is the repetition of the same note in the semiquaver/quaver rhythm, ending in a flutter tongue in the highest E
  • Bars 33-34 are a variation of the motif
  • Bars 35-39 the quavers are used with the staccato
  • Bars 40-43 are a descending of crochets with quavers in between

Part B’ Bars 44-51

The B part is shortened here, leading the listener slowly from the party of the C section to the end. Dynamic returns to piano.

  • Bars 44-47 return to the harmonic scale and to the crochet/quaver rhtyhm
  • Bars 48-51 are the main motif with a few variations

Part A’ Bars 52-58

While this section is slower than the previous one, it is similar to the introduction, ending in the same note as it began, giving it the appearance of being forever looped.

  • Bars 52-55 are similar to bars 5-7 but in a 3/4 time signature
  • Bar 56 is made entirely of crochets
  • Bars 57-58 a little pause to breathe into the instrument and realising the final two notes

References

Adler, S., 2002. The study of orchestration. 3rd ed. New York: W.W. Norton.

2019. Writing for the Clarinet. [pdf] Available at: <https://ymmd.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Writing-for-the-Clarinet-.pdf> [Accessed 14 September 2021].

item.content:encoded:
I do not intend to conduct in-depth analyses of these solo compositions, but rather to concentrate on how the composers wrote for that unique instrument. What techniques they employed, and how they attained various tonalities and colours in relation to each instrument.

Flute

Claude Debussy – Syrinx

Due to the fact that it is likely the first flute solo piece written since the baroque period, Syrinx is one of the most important pieces written for flute solo. More composers were motivated to create for the unaccompanied flute as a result of this (Lee, 2018).

This composition, as well as the growing interest in the flute as a solo instrument, is thought to be attributable to advancements in the instrument, which allowed for new methods and sound colour. Indeed, Debussy explores the flute’s various tonalities and ranges. Consider the motif in the first bar, which is played in a high range with mezzo-forte.

The same motif is repeated, but in a lower range and piano, giving the piece a darker feel.

Debussy uses the flute’s many ranges, travelling from C4 to E6 with multiple wave-like movements, creating a hypnotic sound.

It’s fascinating to hear Debussy move from the piece’s climax to its conclusion using an almost all direct descending line in the final section of Syrinx. At the same time, he goes from a mezzo-forte to a piano. This demonstrates how the flute may go from a loud and detailed high note, suited for demisemiquavers, to a very low register that is calmer, darker, and more sustained.

Oboe

Gordon Jacob – Seven Bagatelles

Gordon Jacob composed seven short solo oboe compositions. The works are all fairly different, demonstrating the oboe’s tonal versatility as a solo instrument.

The oboe’s ability to play a mixture of legato and staccato phrases in a light bouncy style, like in 5 – Limerick, is one example.

In 4 – Slow Air, Jacob also explores the prolonged notes as well as the various dynamics that sound lethargic or sorrowful.

The 2 – Elegy explores the melody lines that fit the oboe so well, as well as the big intervals that provide a wonderful contrast, especially in the high registers.

The oboe’s melodic quality is also evident in the 6 – Chinese Tune, which employs the pentatonic scale.

The potential of the oboe to handle rather large leaps (Adler, 2002) is explored in various pieces, with the 3 – Waltz being one of them.

Saxophone

Paul Creston – Sonata for Alto Saxophone and Piano, Op. 19

I looked for a version of the saxophone solo as suggested, but all I found was the sonata accompanied by the piano. I’m not sure if this is the only version of the sonata available.

Before researching for this piece, I had never heard of Paul Creston, and I was pleased to learn that he was glad to create for often-overlooked instruments (Watanabe, 2011). Indeed, there were not many works dedicated to the saxophone in the 1930s, when this sonata was written (Mauk, 2015), therefore I was intrigued to learn what specific aspects he wrote for this instrument.

This work is structured into three movements, each of which is different. He begins with a jazzy opening, then transitions to a slower second movement before concluding with a more rhythmic movement. This demonstrates a saxophone’s adaptability, which I thought noteworthy.

One thing I observed in the first movement is the tempo shifts, which go from a fast ♩=126 “With vigor” to a calming in bar 10 and then a rise in bar 17. These changes are ideal for the saxophone, which can gracefully handle both slow and quick shifts.

The dynamics of the saxophone in this tune are one of the most noticeable variances. It has a wide range of dynamics, similar to the clarinet, and in this composition, it ranges from pianissimo to fortissimo. However, in contrast to the clarinet, I found the pianissimo not so soft and the fortissimo a little to bright. I’m curious how these dynamic shifts would function in a woodwind ensemble.

The second movement is a little more serene, with long notes that are representative of what one would expect from a saxophone. This movement surprised me least despite being extremely melodic and almost singable.

The third movement, on the other hand, surprised me the most, especially because I wasn’t expecting to hear the saxophone play such a rhythmic role. The saxophone sounds incredibly expressive and almost danceable in this passage, from the main theme to the staccato followed by the marcato.

Bassoon

Willson Osborne – Rhapsody for Bassoon

Just one thing to mention: the C.F. Peters Corp edition of this score has beautiful lettering.

My previous perception of the bassoon was that it is a very melancholy instrument. Wilson Osborne did not mislead me.

Slow parts are no problem for the bassoon, but what amazed me the most was how beautifully the quick runs worked. Osborne was able to arrange it in a very melodious manner, demonstrating the bassoon’s versatility.

The bassoon is a fantastic solo instrument in all registers, but when it’s accompanied, it gets swallowed up by the other instruments (Adler, 2002). That’s why Osborne presumably didn’t stick to the bassoon’s lower registers, opting instead to use the higher register, which is thin yet expressive.

Because the bassoon can’t handle forceful blows, it’s not surprising that Osborne didn’t go over forte in terms of dynamics.

The relative lack of rests was the last thing I noticed that I wasn’t anticipating. The bassoonist, in my opinion, would benefit from more breathing time and lengthier breaks. But I don’t believe Osborne agreed.

Clarinet

item.title: Listening to Tim Maia – Não Quero Dinheiro
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: I was listening to music on Spotify on shuffle when Tim Maia’s Não Quero Dinheiro came on, and…
item.content:encoded:
What makes a happy melody?

I was listening to music on Spotify on shuffle when Tim Maia’s Não Quero Dinheiro came on, and I had a thought: why do I feel happy every time I hear this song, particularly the chorus? I’ll try to figure it out by examining its melody.

Tim Maia was a Brazilian musician who is regarded as one of the country’s most influential musicians. Maia pioneered sambalanço with Jorge Ben, a genre that combines samba, soul, funk, and rock and roll.

In 1971, he recorded Não Quero Dinheiro, a samba/soul song in which he declares, “I don’t want any money, I just want love,” in response to rising consumerism. It’s a love song that’s likely influenced by the peace and love movement of the 1960s. The song went on to become a great success. Note that Brazil was under a dictatorship at the time, and this style of music was used as an escape from oppression.

This song catches my attention because of its general cheerfulness and happiness just by listening to it. This is, in my opinion, to do with repetition, syncopation, and tension.

The song begins with a syncopated melody that is repeated twice before the variation. This is the song’s verse, and while the tone is lively, it does not reach the climax of the chorus.

The chorus is the most joyful element of the song, but Tim Maia’s creation of a hymn with only three notes is even more astounding. And I believe that repetition is the key. In the first part of the chorus, the A is repeated 32 times.

If you listen to this melody alone, especially on the piano, you’ll hear almost a childlike repetition. As if a child was trying to prove she was better than others. It seems like you might be able to sing “My toy is better than yours” in this melody.

This chorus is also characterized by tension. The song repeats itself six times, creating tension, with the hope of resolution which comes in half of the seventh bar. The repetition-tension-resolution game continues throughout the entire melody.

I was delighted to discover this Ted Talk about music repetition by Elizabeth Margulis, Professor and Director of Princeton University’s Music Cognition Lab.

In a nutshell, repetition makes you feel that music is more enjoyable, more interesting and more human. Music critics, according to Margulis, are often embarrassed by repetition, believing it to be childish or regressive; but repetition, far from being embarrassing, helps us to think of music as a way of seeing the world.

Not to be forgotten is Beethoven’s repeated four-note theme in his Symphony No. 5 or Ravel’s Bolero, which is composed entirely of variations on a single motif.

Finally, in my opinion, what makes this melody feel happy and cheery is the same childish repetition that reminds you of a period when life was simple and happy, and all you cared about was playing and being happy. And those joyful memories are made up of repeated memories.
